    As an alternative to the procedure established under section 2-4-5, the board may, by resolution, describe the real property of the city which is to be sold, provide a maximum rate of fee, compensation or commission, and provide that the city reserves the right to reject any and all offers determined to be insufficient. After adoption of the resolution, the board may engage licensed real estate brokers to attempt to sell the described property by way of nonexclusive listing agreements. 
(Code 1979, § 2-02-04.1; Code 1994, § 3-01-08; Ord. No. 735, § 2, 1988) 
ARTICLE 5. - FEES FOR SERVICE 

Sec. 2-5-1. - Implied contract for services. 
    The owner or occupant of any property causing, permitting or using the connection to the city's potable water and sanitary sewer systems by way of such act shall be presumed to have entered into a contract with the city for utility service. Under the terms of the presumed contract, the owner or occupant promises to: 
(1)  Pay for the utility service; 
(2)  Properly maintain the service connections; and 
(3)  Permit entry by authorized city employees for the purposes of water meter inspection, maintenance, repair, replacement or removal and the reading of meters for billing. 
(Code 1979, §§ 6-02-06, 6-02-16, 6-03-17; Code 1994, § 9-04-01) 
Sec. 2-5-2. - Joint and several liabilities of owners and occupants. 
    The owner and occupant of each premises shall be jointly and severally liable for all charges and fees for water, sewage, street lighting, storm drainage, garbage collection and solid waste disposal during the period of their respective ownership or occupancy. In addition to any other remedy, all such charges and fees having been properly billed to the owner or occupant of any premises, served and not paid, may be recovered by the city in a civil action in any court of competent jurisdiction against the owner, the occupant or both. 
(Code 1979, § 6-02-09; Code 1994, § 9-04-02) 
Sec. 2-5-3. - Fees and charges constitute liens upon the premises. 
    All water, sewage, street lighting, storm drainage, garbage collection and solid waste disposal charges or fees for any services supplied, provided or furnished by the city shall constitute liens upon the respective lots, tracts, parcels of land and premises receiving such service. All such charges or fees which have been properly billed to the owner or occupant of the premises served and which are more than 30 days past due on September 30 of each year shall be certified by the city finance director or designee to the county auditor between October 1 and October 10 of each year. The city finance director or designee, in so certifying such charges and fees, shall specify the amount thereof, the description of the premises served and the name of the owner thereof. The amount so certified shall be entered by the county auditor upon the tax rolls against such premises and collected by the county treasurer and paid to the city finance director in the same manner and time as other county and municipal taxes are assessed, certified, collected and returned. 
(Code 1994, § 9-04-03) 
Sec. 2-5-4. - Utility service connection or termination; right to hearing. 
(a)  The city has the right to refuse to connect or reconnect any water or sanitary sewer service or disconnect water service for the following reasons: 
(1)  Failure to meet the applicable provisions of the law. 
(2)  Violation of the rules and regulations pertaining to utility service. 
(3)  Nonpayment of bills. 
(4)  Willful or negligent waste of service due to improper or imperfect pipes, fixtures, appliances or otherwise. 
(5)  Damaging or tampering with any meter, seal or other equipment controlling or regulating the supply of utility service. 
(6)  Theft or diversion and/or use of service without payment. 
(7)  Vacancy of premises. 
(8)  Failure of the consumer or the owner of the property to permit entry of the premises for reading of the city meter, or failure to pay an estimated billing when the city has been unable to obtain entry to the premises to read the city meter. 
(b)  The city shall provide written notice of water service termination to the owner or customer at least fourteen days in advance of disconnecting the service and provide a specific reason for the planned termination of service. The notice shall be sent by regular mail to the address shown on the city's billing receipts and shall include a statement that the recipient of the notice may submit a written demand to the finance director for an informal hearing before the board or its designate. Upon receipt of a written demand for hearing, the planned service termination shall be cancelled and the finance director shall schedule an informal hearing as soon as is practicable. Following the hearing, the board or its designate may order that the utility service be terminated without further delay, make such order that the utility service be terminated if the owner or customer fails to take certain specified actions or make such other reasonable order as may be necessary or appropriate. 
(c)  Whenever water service is disconnected pursuant to this section, a reasonable reconnect fee shall be paid by the owner, customer or successor in interest before reconnection. 
(Code 1979, §§ 6-02-15, 6-03-08; Code 1994, § 9-04-04) 
Sec. 2-5-5. - Tampering prohibited; penalty. 
(a)  Prohibited. No person shall: 
(1)  Tamper with, damage, injure, deface, remove or break the seal on any water meter or other water system component. 
(2)  Break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is a part of the sanitary sewer system. 
(3)  Break, damage, destroy, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is part of the public street lighting system. 
(4)  Break, damage, destroy, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is part of the public storm drainage system. 
(b)  Penalty. 
(1)  A person violating the provisions of this section is guilty of an offense. 
(2)  Upon discovery of any water meter which has been broken, injured or tampered with, whether through intentional or accidental cause, the public works department director shall be empowered to shut off the water to such premises until such time as the same is repaired or replaced. The expense of repairing or replacing any meter shall be a charge against the consumer, shall be billed with the next month's water bill and shall become due and payable as with any other service charge assessed by the city. 
(Code 1979, §§ 6-02-13, 6-03-06; Code 1994, § 9-04-05) 
Sec. 2-5-6. - Sale of service by customer prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to resell any utility service obtained from the city to others except only by special arrangement approved by the board of city commissioners. 
(Code 1979, § 6-02-19; Code 1994, § 9-02-16) 
ARTICLE 6. - PUBLIC RECORDS MANAGEMENT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Public records, N.D.C.C. § 44-04-17.1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-6-1. - Purpose. 
    Except as otherwise specifically provided by law or court order, all records of public and governmental bodies, boards, bureaus, commissions or agencies of any political subdivision supported in whole or in part by public funds shall be public records, open and accessible for inspection during reasonable office hours. This article establishes procedures and fees for the inspection of records and the furnishing of copies of records of the city. Search, prior review and copy services are provided in order to make access to records meaningful. The city has the duty to properly safeguard and protect its records and to ensure that the confidentiality of records which are privileged under the law is maintained. The purpose of charging for record searches, prior review and copies is not to obstruct the furnishing of information but to impose the cost of these services upon the person who seeks the information, rather than upon the general public. 
(Code 1994, § 2-13-01; Ord. No. 811, § 1(0-00-01), 1993) 
Sec. 2-6-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Copy request means a request for a specified number of copies of specified records where the records are sufficiently identified so that no search is required. 
    Prior review means an administrative review of the requested records to protect their confidentiality as required or allowed by law. 
    Record as provided in N.D.C.C. § 44-04-17.1. 
    Search request means any request for inspection or copies of records which are not sufficiently described to permit immediate identification of individual pages or records. 
(Code 1994, § 2-13-02; Ord. No. 811, § 1(0-00-02), 1993) 
Sec. 2-6-3. - Certain records confidential; when prior review required. 
    When a request to review, inspect or copy records of the city may include or compromise information which is privileged under state law, the department head responsible for maintaining and protecting such records shall direct that a prior review of the record be conducted by an appropriate city employee, and the costs of the prior review shall be charged to the person requesting the records. 
(Code 1994, § 2-13-03; Ord. No. 811, § 1(0-00-03), 1993) 
Sec. 2-6-4. - Written request required; services to be prepaid. 
    Any request for inspection of public records or for search or copy services must be in writing on a form provided by the city. If the request is made by telephone or by some other written document, whenever possible, the form should be completed on behalf of the requestor. If the cost of the request exceeds $5.00, no inspection, search or copy services shall be commenced until the cost is paid in advance. If the actual cost of furnishing the services, including the costs of search and prior review, exceeds the advance payment, no copies shall be furnished or inspection allowed until the person requesting services makes payment in full. 
(Code 1994, § 2-13-04; Ord. No. 811, § 1(0-00-04), 1993) 
Sec. 2-6-5. - Response time; inspections supervised. 
    The regular and ordinary duties of city employees responsible for response to search and copy requests are of primary importance and take precedence over such requests. Search and copy requests are to be attended to as promptly as is reasonably possible without delaying accomplishment of primary duties. Requests to inspect records which may require search or prior review to protect confidential matters shall be subject to reasonable rules and regulations as to when, where and how inspection may be made. To safeguard public records and prevent the alteration or loss of records, all inspections must be supervised. 
(Code 1994, § 2-13-05; Ord. No. 811, § 1(0-00-05), 1993) 
Sec. 2-6-6. - Components and waiver of fees. 
    The full cost to the city of any copy, search or prior review services shall be calculated and charged to the person requesting those services. The city finance director may waive charges for these services in the following circumstances: 
(1)  Copy requests totaling less than ten sides or impressions and requiring no search or prior review. 
(2)  Requests made by governmental officials or their agents who require the information in order to carry out their official responsibilities and duties. 
(3)  Requests made by attorneys on behalf of clients involved in current civil or criminal actions in which the city is a party and is required by court rule or order to disclose public records. 
(4)  Requests for which the city determines that a waiver of charges would be in the best interest of the city. 
(Code 1994, § 2-13-07; Ord. No. 811, § 1(0-00-07), 1993) 
Sec. 2-6-7. - Search and prior review fees. 
    Search and prior review fees shall be charged based upon the fee schedule set forth in N.D.C.C. § 44-04-18(2). 
(Code 1994, § 2-13-08; Ord. No. 811, § 1(0-00-08), 1993; Ord. No. 1034, 1-29-2008) 
Sec. 2-6-8. - Copy fees. 
    The fee for copying documents shall be $0.25 per page. There is no additional charge for time spent by the operator of copying equipment if the time required to provide the copying service is less than one hour. If the time required to provide the copying service is more than one hour, a service fee equal to that provided for search and prior review services shall be charged. If the copy request concerns a record which cannot be readily photocopied, copies may be made in any reasonable manner and a copy charge shall be equal to the total cost of the production of the copies. 
(Code 1994, § 2-13-09; Ord. No. 811, § 1(0-00-09), 1993; Ord. No. 1286, 4-3-2018; Ord. No. 1288, 5-15-2018) 
Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Alcoholic beverages, N.D.C.C. title 5; local regulation of retail sales of alcohol, N.D.C.C. § 5-02-09. 

ARTICLE 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Growler means a glass bottle not to exceed 64 ounces that is filled with beer by a licensee or an employee of a licensee with beer from a keg. The sale of growlers, in compliance with this chapter, is authorized only for licensees approved to sell alcoholic beverages both on-sale and off-sale. The filling of growlers by means of tapped keg shall not constitute the breaking of a package. Growlers may only be filled from kegs procured by the licensee from a duly licensed wholesaler or produced by the licensee pursuant to applicable laws. Only professionally sanitized and sealed growlers may be filled and made available for retail sale. The sale of a filled growler shall be considered off-sale. A growler with a broken seal shall be considered an open container. 
    Licensed premises means: 
(1)  The rooms within a building, including the bar area, dining room, banquet or meeting rooms and all other areas, spaces or rooms where alcoholic beverages are regularly or occasionally sold, served, dispensed or consumed by patrons; 
(2)  An enclosed patio structure permanently affixed to the building of the licensed premises which has been approved under the provisions of section 4-1-11; 
(3)  A temporary site off and away from the licensed premises which has been approved by the board under the provisions of sections 4-2-6 or 4-2-9; or 
(4)  A publicly owned or operated facility which has been granted a special permit under the provisions of section 4-2-9. 
    Licensee means any person to whom a license has been issued to sell alcoholic beverages by the city. 
    Lodge or club means any corporation or association organized for civil, fraternal, social or business purposes, or for the promotion of sports, which has at least 200 members at the time a license is applied for pursuant to this chapter, and was in existence on November 3, 1936. 
    Off-sale means the sale of all alcoholic beverages in the original package for consumption off or away from the licensed premises where sold, and upon which premises the consumption of alcoholic beverages is unlawful; provided, however, that this provision shall not prohibit the licensee from dispensing and the customer from consuming a free sample of wine as defined by the laws of this state. 
    On-sale means the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption only on the licensed premises where sold. 
    Package and original package means any container or receptacle holding alcoholic beverages which is corked or sealed by the manufacturer and which cork or seal has not been removed or broken prior to the sale of such package to the customer. 
    Sale means any transfer, exchange or barter in any manner or by any means whatsoever for a consideration. The term "sale" includes all sales made by any person, whether principal proprietor, agent, servant or employee. 
    Sale at retail means a sale to a customer for use or consumption and not for the purpose of resale in any form. 
    Wholesaler means any person engaged in the sale and distribution of alcoholic beverages at wholesale to persons holding a retail license for the sale and distribution of alcoholic beverages within the state or in interstate commerce. 
(Code 1979, § 10-02-01; Code 1994, § 12-01-01; Ord. No. 645, § 1, 1981; Ord. No. 683, § 1, 1985; Ord. No. 709, § 1, 1986; Ord. No. 752, § 1, 1989; Ord. No. 1161, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 4-1-2. - Application. 
(a)  This chapter is declared to be an exercise of the police power directly affecting and designed to promote peace, safety, good order, health and well-being of the people of the city. This chapter shall apply to all territory within the city and to such outlying contiguous territory without the corporate limits within which the city may exercise police jurisdiction as defined by law. 
(b)  All licenses or permits issued by the city pursuant to this chapter confer a privilege on the license holder to engage in the activity or occupation so licensed, and do not constitute property or property rights or create any such rights in any license holder or applicant. No license or permit issued under this chapter may be mortgaged, encumbered, pledged, seized, levied upon, attached, executed upon, assessed or in any manner taken for the purpose of securing, or in satisfaction of, any debt, judgment, lien, mortgage, encumbrance or obligation. 
(Code 1979, § 10-02-02; Code 1994, § 12-01-02; Ord. No. 1116, 4-17-2012) 
Sec. 4-1-3. - Hours and time of sale. 
    A person may not sell or dispense, or permit the sale, dispensation or consumption, of alcoholic beverages on licensed premises at any time when prohibited by state law or city ordinances, unless otherwise permitted by the decision of a court of competent jurisdiction. A person may not dispense or permit the consumption of alcoholic beverages on a licensed premises between 1:00 a.m. and 11:00 a.m. on Sundays, and between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. of all other days of the week. All drinks, glasses and beverage containers must be collected and emptied or disposed of as soon as practicable at the legally required time of closing or immediately thereafter. 
(Code 1979, § 10-02-03; Code 1994, § 12-01-03; Ord. No. 645, § 2, 1981; Ord. No. 724, § 1, 1987; Ord. No. 809, § 1, 1993; Ord. No. 1234, 2-2-2016) 
State Law reference- Days and hours of sale, N.D.C.C. § 5-02-05 et seq. 
Sec. 4-1-4. - Location. 
(a)  General. No class A, class D or class D-1 license shall be issued to cover any location within 300 feet of the property line of property whereon is located any school, church, public or parochial school, public library, hospital, college or university building used for academic purposes, unless the entities affected by the above limitation consents to the issuance of the license. No license shall entitle the holder, except lodges and clubs, to carry on such business at retail except on the first floor above or on ground level; however, hotels and motels may deliver to their guests for consumption in their rooms. 
(b)  Retail alcoholic beverage license. No retail liquor license, whether general or off-sale, shall be issued for any building, room or place not directly adjoining a public street. 
(c)  Gas stations, grocery stores and convenience stores. No retail off-sale alcoholic beverage license shall be issued to a person whose business to be licensed is located in a building that is primarily a gas station, grocery store or convenience store, unless the area to be licensed for the sale of alcoholic beverages is clearly set out in a blueprint or diagram and is separated from the nonlicensed portion of the business by a wall designed to allow sales personnel to serve customers and make sales in both the licensed and unlicensed portions of the premises and that may allow customers in either portion of the premises access to the other. 
(Code 1979, § 10-02-04; Code 1994, § 12-01-04; Ord. No. 1114, 4-17-2012) 
Sec. 4-1-5. - Possess or use by underage persons; presence in licensed premises. 
(a)  Except as permitted in this section and section 4-1-7, an individual under 21 years of age may not manufacture or attempt to manufacture, purchase or attempt to purchase, consume or have recently consumed other than during a religious service, be under the influence of, be in possession of, or furnish money to any individual for the purchase of an alcoholic beverage. 
(b)  An individual under 21 years of age may not enter any licensed premises where alcoholic beverages are being sold or displayed, except: 
(1)  A restaurant, if accompanied by a parent or legal guardian; 
(2)  In accordance with section 4-1-7; 
(3)  If the individual is an independent contractor or the independent contractor's employee engaged in contract work and is not engaged in selling, dispensing, delivering, or consuming alcoholic beverages; 
(4)  If the individual is a law enforcement officer or other public official who enters the premises in the performance of official duty; or 
(5)  If the individual enters the premises for training, education, or research purposes under the supervision of an individual 21 or more years of age with prior notification of the local licensing authority. 
(c)  An individual under 21 years of age is immune from criminal prosecution under this section if that individual contacted law enforcement or emergency medical services and reported that another individual under 21 years of age was in need of medical assistance due to alcohol consumption, provided assistance to the individual in need of medical assistance until assistance arrived and remained on the scene, or was the individual in need of medical assistance and cooperated with medical assistance and law enforcement personnel on the scene. The maximum number of individuals that may be immune for any one occurrence is five individuals. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, N.D.C.C. § 5-01-08. 
Sec. 4-1-6. - Sale to certain persons prohibited. 
(a)  Any person who shall knowingly deliver alcoholic beverages to an individual under 21 years of age, except as allowed under section 4-1-7, or to a habitual drunkard, an incompetent, or an obviously intoxicated individual is guilty of a Class B misdemeanor, subject to section 4-1-5. 
(b)  An individual under 21 years of age is immune from prosecution under this section if that individual contacted law enforcement or emergency medical services and reported that another individual under 21 years of age was in need of medical assistance due to alcohol consumption, provided assistance to the individual in need of medical assistance until assistance arrived and remained on the scene and cooperated with medical assistance and law enforcement personnel on the scene, or was the individual in need of medical assistance. The maximum number of individuals that may be immune for any one occurrence is five individuals. 
(c)  If an individual is convicted of this section for delivering alcoholic beverages to an individual under 21 years of age, the court shall consider the following in mitigation: 
(1)  After consuming the alcohol, the underage individual was in need of medical assistance as a result of consuming alcohol; and 
(2)  Within 12 hours after the underage individual consumed the alcohol, the defendant contacted law enforcement or emergency medical personnel to report that the underage individual was in need of medical assistance as a result of consuming alcohol. 
(Code 1979, § 10-02-05; Code 1994, § 12-01-05) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, N.D.C.C. § 5-01-09. 
Sec. 4-1-7. - Dispensing to underage persons; presence in licensed establishments. 
(a)  Except as permitted in this section, a licensee who dispenses alcoholic beverages to an individual under 21 years of age, or who permits an individual under 21 years of age to remain on the licensed premises while alcoholic beverages are being sold or displayed, is guilty of a Class B misdemeanor, subject to section 4-1-5. 
(b)  No person under 21 years of age shall be employed in or about any premises licensed under N.D.C.C. chs. 5-01, 5-02, 5-03 or 5-04, except as provided in this section. 
(c)  An individual under 21 years of age may not remain in a restaurant where alcoholic beverages are being sold except if the restaurant is separated from the room in which alcoholic beverages are opened or mixed and gross sales of food are at least equal to gross sales of alcoholic beverages which are consumed in the dining area, or if the individual is employed by the restaurant as a food waiter, food waitress, busboy, or busgirl, under the direct supervision of an individual 21 or more years of age and is not engaged in the sale, dispensing, delivery, or consumption of alcoholic beverages. 
(d)  An individual under 21 years of age may enter and remain on the licensed premises if the individual is an independent contractor or the independent contractor's employee engaged in contract work and is not engaged in selling, dispensing, delivering, or consuming alcoholic beverages; if the individual is a law enforcement officer or other public official who enters the premises in the performance of official duty; or if the individual enters the licensed premises for training, education, or research purposes under the supervision of an individual 21 or more years of age with prior notification of the local licensing authority. 
(e)  An individual under 21 years of age may remain in an area of a site where beer, wine, or sparkling wine is sold in accordance with the conditions of an event permit issued pursuant to N.D.C.C. § 5-02-01.1. 
(f)  An individual who is 18 years of age or older but under 21 years of age may be employed by a restaurant as provided in subsection (b) of this section to serve and collect money for alcoholic beverages, if the individual is under the direct supervision of an individual 21 or more years of age, but may not be engaged in mixing, dispensing, or consuming alcoholic beverages. Any establishment where alcoholic beverages are sold may employ individuals from 18 to 21 years of age to work in the capacity of musicians under the direct supervision of an individual 21 or more years of age. 
(g)  For purposes of this section, an individual is not 21 years of age until 8:00 a.m. on that individual's 21st birthday. 
(h)  If an individual is convicted of this section, the court shall consider the following in mitigation: 
(1)  After consuming the alcohol, the underage individual was in need of medical assistance as a result of consuming alcohol; and 
(2)  Within 12 hours after the underage individual consumed the alcohol, the defendant contacted law enforcement or emergency medical personnel to report that the underage individual was in need of medical assistance as a result of consuming alcohol. 
(Code 1979, §§ 10-02-06, 10-02-07; Code 1994, §§ 12-01-06, 12-01-07; Ord. No. 752, § 2, 1989) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, N.D.C.C. § 5-02-06. 
Sec. 4-1-8. - Misrepresentation of age; licensee may keep book. 
    Any person who misrepresents or misstates that person's age or the age of any other person or who misrepresents that person's age through presentation of any document purporting to show that person to be of legal age to purchase alcoholic beverages is guilty of a Class B misdemeanor. Any licensee may keep a book and may require anyone who has shown documentary proof of that person's age, which substantiates that person's age to allow the purchase of alcoholic beverages, to sign the book if the age of that person is in question. The book must show the date of the purchase, the identification used in making the purchase and the appropriate numbers of such identification, the address of the purchaser, and the purchaser's signature. 
(Code 1979, §§ 10-02-08, 10-02-09; Code 1994, §§ 12-01-08, 12-01-09) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, N.D.C.C. § 5-01-08.1. 
Sec. 4-1-9. - Presumption of licensee's innocence when certain facts established relative to underage persons. 
    The establishment of the following facts by a person making a sale of alcoholic beverages to a person not of legal age constitutes prima facie evidence of innocence and a defense to any prosecution therefor: 
(1)  That the purchaser falsely represented and supported with other documentary proof that the purchaser was of legal age to purchase alcoholic beverages. 
(2)  That the appearance of the purchaser was such that an ordinary and prudent person would believe the purchaser to be of legal age to purchase alcoholic beverages. 
(3)  That the sale was made in good faith and in reliance upon the representation and appearance of the purchaser in the belief that the purchaser was of legal age to purchase alcoholic beverages. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, N.D.C.C. § 5-01-08.2. 
Sec. 4-1-10. - Sale or use on streets prohibited. 
(a)  This section does not apply to persons in motor vehicles. 
(b)  Except as may be permitted under article 3 of this chapter, the sale or serving of alcoholic beverages or the possession of any open receptacle containing any alcoholic beverages upon any street, alley or public way is prohibited. 
(c)  Except as may be permitted under article 3 of this chapter, the consumption of alcoholic beverages upon any street, alley, or public way located within any commercial zoning district or upon any lot adjacent to any licensed alcoholic beverage premises is prohibited. 
(d)  A violation of this section is an infraction. 
(Code 1979, § 10-02-10; Code 1994, § 12-01-10; Ord. No. 627, § 1, 1980; Ord. No. 922, 6-19-2001) 
State Law reference- Possession of alcohol in motor vehicles, N.D.C.C. § 39-08-18. 
Sec. 4-1-11. - Sale or use outside licensed premises prohibited; exception. 
    The sale, service, dispensing or consumption of alcoholic beverages off of the licensed premises is prohibited, except under the following conditions: 
(1)  Where made in accordance with a special permit granted by the board under the provisions of sections 4-2-17 or 4-2-20; or 
(2)  Where made within a patio structure which is permanently affixed to the licensed premises and which meets the following criteria: 
a.  Access to the patio structure may be made only through the licensed premises; 
b.  The patio structure must be permanently enclosed or fenced at a minimum height of 36 inches to prevent entrance other than through the licensed premises; provided, however, that said fence must have a gate as required by the International Fire Code currently in effect; 
c.  The licensee shall file with the building inspector a site plan showing the location, plans and specifications of the proposed enclosure in relation to the licensed structure and the lot lines of the premises. The proposed plan must be approved by the building inspector and fire chief; and 
d.  The enclosed patio area does not exceed the total square footage of the licensed premises to which it is attached. 
(Code 1979, § 10-01-10.1; Code 1994, § 12-01-10.1; Ord. No. 738, § 1, 1988; Ord. No. 752, § 4, 1989; Ord. No. 1058, § 2(b), (c), 6-30-2009) 
Sec. 4-1-12. - Licensee responsible for conduct of place of business. 
    Every licensee is made responsible for the conduct of his place of business and is required to maintain order and sobriety in such place of business. No intoxicated person shall be permitted to remain upon the premises or to be sold beer, liquor or alcoholic beverages by any person holding any license issued pursuant to this chapter. 
(Code 1979, § 10-02-11; Code 1994, § 12-01-11) 
Sec. 4-1-13. - Screens, booths, enclosures or partitions prohibited on on-sale premises. 
    No on-sale licensee shall construct, maintain or suffer or cause to be constructed, placed or maintained any side room, any closed booth, or other enclosures or partition in any part of the premises for which a license has been or is to be issued. All of the premises, except necessary storerooms and spaces not used for the sale of alcoholic beverages, shall be open and freely accessible from any and all parts of the interior of such premises without obstruction, by any door, partition screen, curtain, blind or any other type of enclosure or wall. All booths and areas within said premises, except storerooms and spaces not used for the sale of beer, shall be freely accessible from all parts of the interior of said premises. No booths shall be more than 50 inches high, nor have thereon any screen, curtain, partition or blind or obstruction of any kind preventing a clear view into said booth from the main room and aisle of said premises. 
(Code 1979, § 10-02-12; Code 1994, § 12-01-12) 
Sec. 4-1-14. - Gambling devices prohibited. 
    No license shall be issued under this chapter to cover any locations where any slot machine or other gambling device is operated or kept upon the premises, or in any part of the building for which a license is issued. The keeping or operation of said gambling devices or slot machines shall be cause for the cancellation or revoking of any license that may have been issued for said premises. The provisions of this section shall not prohibit the keeping or operating of any device or games of chance which have been duly licensed under the provisions of the laws of this state. 
(Code 1979, § 10-02-14; Code 1994, § 12-01-13; Ord. No. 645, § 3, 1981) 
Sec. 4-1-15. - Health regulations for on-sale establishments. 
    No on-sale license shall be granted for any premises unless adequate and sufficient lavatories and toilets, separately maintained for men and women, and kept in a clean and sanitary condition, are at all times readily available to patrons and handicapped accessible; and no license shall be issued unless adequate sanitary provisions are made for the conduct of business. An on-sale license may be revoked where the foregoing requirements or any other health ordinances or regulations are not at all times strictly observed. 
(Code 1979, § 10-02-15; Code 1994, § 12-01-14) 
Sec. 4-1-16. - Purchases to be from licensed wholesaler. 
    No licensee under this chapter shall purchase, have or possess any beer, liquor or alcoholic beverages unless he has purchased the same from a wholesaler duly licensed under the laws of this state. Each licensee under this chapter shall keep on file all invoices covering purchases by him of beer, liquor or alcoholic beverages showing the name and license number of the wholesaler and the name of the municipality issuing such wholesale license. Such records shall be retained in possession of the licensee and at all times shall be open to inspection by any peace officer of this state. 
(Code 1979, § 10-02-16; Code 1994, § 12-01-15) 
Sec. 4-1-17. - Records. 
    Each licensee under this chapter shall keep a book showing the kind and quantities of all beer, liquor or alcoholic beverages purchased by him, together with the name of the person from whom purchased, the license number of the wholesaler selling such beer, liquor or alcoholic beverages to said licensee and the name of the municipality issuing such wholesale license. 
(Code 1979, § 10-02-17; Code 1994, § 12-01-16) 
Sec. 4-1-18. - Tax must be paid. 
    Other than as regulated by N.D.C.C. ch. 5-03, no alcohol or alcoholic beverage as defined in N.D.C.C. title 5, shall be permitted to be owned, held or possessed on any premises licensed for retail sale unless taxes on said alcohol or alcoholic beverage have been paid. The possession of any container of any kind in which such alcohol or alcoholic beverage is found which does not bear the evidence of such tax being paid shall be deemed to be illegal and in violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1979, § 10-02-18; Code 1994, § 12-01-17) 
Sec. 4-1-19. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1262, § (1), adopted June 6, 2017, effective August 1, 2017, repealed § 4-1-19, which pertained to special Sunday off-sale alcoholic beverage permit authorized; tax and restrictions imposed and derived from Code 1994, § 12-01-17.1; Ord. No. 834, §§ 1-4, adopted May 2, 1995. 
Sec. 4-1-20. - Entertainment and live performances upon the licensed premises. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Entertainment means all forms and types of performing or entertaining for patrons on licensed premises without regard to whether such entertainment is provided by means of live performances or manually operated, or electronic systems designed for stereophonic playback of prerecorded signals. However, the term "entertainment" does not include the use of any television, radio or coin-operated music machine subject to the restrictions in subsection (c) of this section. 
    Live performances means any person who, for consideration, monetary or otherwise, performs in person on a licensed premises as a singer, musician, dancer, comedian, model or any other type of entertainer. 
(b)  No alcohol beverage licensee under this chapter shall permit entertainment for more than one day a week any given week without first having obtained a cabaret license as provided in this chapter. The licensing procedure for cabarets shall be governed by the provisions of chapter 12, article 1. 
(c)  The annual license fee for a cabaret license shall be as established by resolution. The license shall be for a period of one year from July 1 to June 30 and shall be payable in advance at the time of the issuance of the license and thereafter, on or before June 30 of each subsequent year for renewal of said license. 
(d)  The application for a cabaret license shall be made by the licensee on forms provided by the city administrator's office. The granting of a cabaret license shall be subject to the approval of the board and it may be suspended or revoked in conformance with procedures established under article 2 of this chapter. 
(e)  A licensee shall have the duty and responsibility to make available for inspection by a member of the police department an identification card, such as a driver's license, containing a photograph and the age of all entertainers or performers on the licensed premises. The licensee shall not permit a person to make a live performance on the licensed premises if the licensee is not able to obtain the required identification from the performer. 
(f)  If any licensee, or any agent, servant or employee, shall violate any provision of this section, the license of such premises may be revoked for cause in accordance with the procedures established pursuant to section 12-9-5. 
(Code 1979, § 10-02-25; Code 1994, § 12-01-18; Ord. No. 708, § 1, 1986; Ord. No. 961, § 1, 6-17-2003) 
Sec. 4-1-21. - Application of prohibited entertainment and live performances to extraterritorial jurisdiction. 
    Section 4-1-20 and any related licensing and zoning ordinances shall apply to all territory within the corporate limits of the city and, as permitted by state law, to such outlying contiguous territory without the corporate limits within which the city may exercise police and zoning jurisdiction. 
(Code 1994, § 12-01-19; Ord. No. 961, § 2, 6-17-2003) 
ARTICLE 2. - LICENSES AND PERMITS 

Sec. 4-2-1. - License required. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to engage in the sale of beer, liquor or alcoholic beverages within the city without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(b)  This section does not apply to public carriers engaged in interstate commerce. 
(c)  This section does not apply to a nonprofit organization that sells an alcoholic beverage as part of a fundraising activity. As used in this section, the term "fundraising activity" includes an auction, raffle, or other prize contest for which consideration is given. If the alcoholic beverage is sold as part of a fundraising event, the sale may not be for consumption at that event. 
(Code 1979, § 10-03-01; Code 1994, § 12-02-01) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, N.D.C.C. § 5-02-01. 
Sec. 4-2-2. - Qualifications. 
(a)  Generally. In addition to qualifications or other requirements which may be prescribed by the laws of this state or by the ordinances or resolutions of this city, no license shall be issued to any applicant unless the applicant files a sworn application completed in full, accompanied by the required fee, showing that he possesses the following qualifications: 
(1)  Individual. If the applicant is an individual, the applicant and the applicant's manager, if any, must: 
a.  Be a legal resident of the United States. 
b.  Have a legal and bona fide residence in the state at the time of applying for such license and maintain such residency during the entire term of such license. 
c.  Be over the age of 21 years. 
d.  Be of good moral character. 
e.  Not have had revoked in the previous years any license for the sale of alcoholic beverages issued to him by any city, county or state. 
f.  Be the owner or lessee of the licensed premises during the entire period licensed. 
g.  Provide satisfactory documentation showing that the building in which the business is conducted meets all local and state requirements regarding sanitation and safety. 
h.  Provide documentary proof that the property taxes for the building in which the licensed premises are located are not delinquent. 
(2)  Partnership. If the applicant is a partnership, the manager of the licensed premises must possess all of the qualifications required of an individual applicant. The partners must be legal residents of the United States and persons of good moral character. 
(3)  Corporation. If the applicant is a corporation for profit: 
a.  It must be registered with the Secretary of State of the State of North Dakota and authorized to do business in this state; 
b.  The manager of the licensed premises and any officer, director or stockholder who is engaged or employed at the licensed premises in any capacity in the conduct of the business of the licensed premises must possess all of the qualifications required of an individual applicant. The officers, directors and stockholders must be legal residents of the United States and persons of good moral character. 
(4)  Lodge or club. If the applicant is a lodge or club, the manager or any person who is in charge of day-to-day operations of the licensed premises must possess the qualification required of an individual applicant. 
(b)  Prohibited. 
(1)  A license may not be issued to an applicant if the applicant, manager or any partner, officer, director or stockholder engaged or employed at the licensed premises in any capacity has been convicted of any of the following offenses within the previous five years, and it is determined that that person has not been rehabilitated within the meaning of N.D.C.C. § 12.1-33-02.1, or that the offense has a direct bearing upon the person's ability to serve the public as an alcoholic beverage retailer: 
a.  Any felony. 
b.  Any offense involving the manufacture, sale, distribution or possession for sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages. 
c.  Any offense involving the sale of drugs or felony possession of drugs. 
d.  Prostitution. 
e.  Obscenity. 
f.  Two or more convictions for driving or being in actual physical control of a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating beverages or drugs. 
g.  Any other offense determined by the board to have a direct bearing on the person's ability to serve the public as an alcoholic beverage retailer. 
In the application of this subsection, it shall be presumed that a violation of subsections (b)(1)a, b, c, d, e, or f of this section has a direct bearing on the person's ability to serve the public. 
(2)  No license shall be issued to any person engaged in business as the representative or agent of another, and a license will be issued only to the owner of the business to be conducted at the location for which the license is sought. Except in the case of an applicant for a special class B or class C liquor establishment license, no applicant shall directly or indirectly, own, control or have any interest whatsoever in any other liquor establishment which is licensed to sell beer or liquor within the city. 
(3)  No applicant shall enter into any agreement or understanding with any other person with respect to the use, operation and management of any beer or liquor establishment licensed within the city which shall in any way contravene the qualification requirements contained in this chapter. 
(c)  Revocation of license. Any misstatement or concealment of facts in the application shall be grounds for revocation of the license issued thereon. 
(Code 1979, § 10-03-02; Code 1994, § 12-02-02; Ord. No. 645, § 4, 1981; Ord. No. 666, § 1, 1983; Ord. No. 770, § 1, 1990; Ord. No. 783, § 1, 1991) 
State Law reference- General qualifications for licenses, N.D.C.C. § 5-02-02. 
Sec. 4-2-3. - Application. 
    Any person desiring a license to sell alcoholic beverages shall file a written, sworn application with the city administrator, containing the following information: 
(1)  Name and residence. The name and legal residence of the applicant and the place of residence of the applicant for a period of one year preceding the date of the application. In the event the applicant is a corporation, the names and legal residences of all persons holding one percent or more of capital stock of the corporation. If the applicant is a partnership, the name and legal residence of each and every member of the partnership. 
(2)  Evidence of incorporation. If the applicant is a corporation, the following information shall be provided to the city: 
a.  The date of the incorporation and the state where incorporated; 
b.  The amount of the authorized capital stock; 
c.  The amount paid in capital, the purpose for which the corporation was incorporated; 
d.  The names and addresses of the officers, directors and managing agents of the corporation; and 
e.  Whether the corporation is a subsidiary of any corporation and, if so, the name of the parent corporation, and the names and addresses of the officers, directors and managing agents of the parent corporation. 
A copy of the certificate of authority issued by the Secretary of State of the State of North Dakota issued to the applicant and the parent corporation, must be attached to the application. 
(3)  Location and site plan. The location by legal and other appropriate and specific description of the place for which the license is sought and a site plan which specifically delineates the rooms and enclosed patio areas, if any, of the building in which the applicant intends to sell, serve, dispense or consume alcoholic beverages. 
(4)  Sanitation, safety and building standards. The applicant must provide documentation establishing that the building in which the business is to be conducted meets local and state requirements regarding sanitation, safety and building regulations. 
(5)  Name and address of the owner of the premises. The name and address of the owner of the premises for which the license is sought. If the license is sought by a person other than the owner of the premises, the general terms of the lease under which the applicant holds possession of the premises, including the period covered by the lease and the rental to be paid. At the request of the board, the applicant shall furnish a copy of the lease under which he holds possession of the premises. If a license is sought by the owner of the premises, the applicant shall state the date on which the applicant acquired title thereto. 
(6)  Delinquent taxes. Whether there are any delinquent taxes against such property. 
(7)  Previous business; alcoholic beverages. Whether the applicant has ever engaged in the sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages prior to this application, and, if so, giving the time and type of business and the place where so engaged, whether within or without the state. 
(8)  Record of license termination. Whether the applicant has ever had a license of any kind revoked or cancelled by any municipal, state or federal authority, including a license for the sale or distribution of any alcoholic beverages, and if so, the time and place of such cancellation, the authority cancelling the same, and the reason for such cancellation. 
(9)  Record of conviction for violation. Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a violation of any municipal, state or federal law relating to the manufacture, sale, distribution or possession of any alcoholic beverages, and if so, the date of the conviction, the name of the violation for which convicted and the court which exercised jurisdiction over the matter. Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of any other local, state or federal offense, and, if so, the date of the conviction, the name of the crime for which convicted, the amount and terms of the sentence imposed, and the court in which convicted. 
(10)  Associates. The names and addresses of all persons who will have charge, management or control of the establishment for which a license is requested. 
(11)  Other interests. Whether any person other than the applicant has any right, title, estate or interest in the lease hold or in the furniture, fixtures or equipment in the premises for which the license is requested, and if so, the name and address of the person, and a statement of the interest so held. 
(12)  Other agreements. Whether the applicant has any agreement, understanding or intention to have any agreement or understanding with any person to obtain for any other person or transfer to any other person the license for which the application is made or to obtain for any purpose other than for the specified use of the applicant, and if so, the name and address of such person and the conditions of such agreement. 
(13)  Interest in other establishments; alcoholic beverages. Whether the applicant has any interest whatsoever, directly or indirectly, in any other alcoholic beverage establishment either at wholesale or retail, within or without the state, and, if so, the names and addresses of such establishments. This provision includes the holders of stock in any corporation dealing in liquor or alcoholic beverages either at wholesale or retail and within the borders of the United States. 
(14)  Occupational record. A list of the occupations in which the applicant has followed during the last ten years. 
(15)  Business references. The names and addresses of at least three business references. 
(16)  Commercial rating. Whether the applicant is rated by any commercial agency, and if so, the name and address of such agency. 
(17)  Additional businesses. Whether the applicant is engaged in any business other than that for which the license is sought or intends to engage in any business other than for the sale of alcoholic beverages under the license applied for, and, if so, the type of business, and if an employee, the name and address of such employer. 
(18)  Type of license. The specific kind of license applied for. 
(19)  Lodges or clubs. Where the license is sought for a lodge or club, the date of the organization of such club, the number of members therein, the purpose for which organized and the purpose for which profits to be derived from the business engaged in pursuant to such license are to be applied and, whenever required by the board, a list of members belonging to the lodge or club. 
(20)  Inspection. A consent to allow city officials and police officers to enter the premises described at any time for inspection. 
(21)  Authorization. Evidence that the applicant has all permits or licenses required by the state or federal government. 
(22)  Other. Such other information as the board, by resolution, may require. 
(Code 1979, § 10-03-03; Code 1994, § 12-02-03; Ord. No. 752, § 5, 1989) 
Sec. 4-2-4. - Classification of alcoholic beverage licenses. 
(a)  The city may issue an unlimited number of alcoholic beverage licenses of any class. There shall be nine classes of alcoholic beverage licenses, namely: 
(1)  Class A. General retail (on- and off-premises) license; requires a minimum seating capacity of 30 persons). 
(2)  Class B. Club (on- and off-premises) license to be issued only to clubs and lodges whose profits from the sale of alcoholic beverages are used only for benevolent purposes. 
(3)  Special B. Publicly owned or operated facilities. 
a.  A license for the retail on-sale of beer only at the manager's building may be issued to the manager of the Municipal Golf Course designated by the Mandan Park District, which shall be nontransferable and shall be held only for the period of the manager's contract and shall terminate with the termination of his contract. The annual license fee shall be as established by resolution for that portion of the year in which such golf course is open. This license shall be limited to the service of beer only to the patrons at the Municipal Golf Course and not open to the public at large. 
b.  A license for the retail on-sale of beer only at the Dacotah Centennial Park may be issued to the concessionaire designated by the Mandan Park District, which shall be nontransferable and shall be held only for the period of the concessionaire's contract and shall terminate with the termination of the contract. The annual license fee shall be as established by resolution for that portion of the year in which such park is open. This license shall be limited to the service of beer only to the patrons of the Dacotah Centennial Park and not open to the public at large. 
c.  Subject to the approval of the board, a temporary license for the distribution or retail on-sale of alcoholic beverages may be issued to the managers of the Municipal Golf Course and the Prairie West Golf Course designated by the Mandan Park District, which shall be nontransferable and shall be held only for the period of a special event, not to exceed three days and shall terminate with the termination of the event. The board may set restrictions, limitations or conditions upon the temporary license. The annual license fee shall be as established by resolution. This license shall be limited to the service or sale of alcoholic beverages to the patrons at the golf courses and not open to the public at large. The licensee may distribute or sell alcoholic beverages during the special event either in the club house or on the golf course, using beverage carts, provided that the sale or distribution is only by a person 21 years of age or older. 
d.  Subject to the approval of the board, a temporary license for the distribution or retail on-sale of alcoholic beverages at the Dacotah Centennial Park may be issued to the concessionaire designated by the Mandan Park District, which shall be nontransferable and shall be held only for the period of a special event, not to exceed three days, and shall terminate with the termination of the event. The board may set restrictions, limitations, or conditions upon the license. The license fee per event shall be as established by resolution. This license shall be limited to the service or sale of alcoholic beverages to the patrons of the Dacotah Centennial Park and not open to the public large and distribution or sale may only be by a person 21 years of age or older. 
e.  Persons or entities holding a special class B beer only licenses are eligible applicants under the provisions of section 4-2-19 relating to special Sunday permits but they are not eligible applicants for a special catering permit under the provisions of section 4-2-16. In making application for a special Sunday permit under the provisions of section 4-2-19, the application must be in the name of the public facility and signed by the president of the park board, or the duly authorized park board representative and the holder of the special class B beer only license. 
(4)  Class C. Motel and hotel (on- and off-premises) license to be issued to the owner or lessee of hotels and motels having 40 or more sleeping rooms, provided that such license may not be transferred to another location and only one licensee may carry on business in the hotel or motel. 
(5)  Class D. Exclusive retail off-sale alcoholic beverages. 
(6)  Class D-1. Exclusive retail off-sale beer and wine. 
(7)  Class E. Food and beverage license, permitting on-premises alcoholic beverage sales, subject to the following restrictions and conditions: 
a.  A licensee may sell alcoholic beverages in a restaurant separated from the room in which alcoholic beverages are sold, if the gross sales of food are at least equal to the sales of alcoholic beverages in the dining room. 
b.  On-premises only. The food and beverage license shall be for on-premises alcoholic beverage sales only, and no authority is conferred under said license pursuant to this section to engage in the off-sale alcoholic beverage business. 
c.  Location. Once a food and beverage license has been established at a particular location, no transfer of the license to another location may be permitted. A cessation of business at a licensed location for a period of 30 days or longer shall automatically cancel the license. 
(8)  Class F. Food and beverage license permitting on-premises beer and wine sales subject to the restrictions and conditions applicable to a Class E license set forth in subsection (a)(7) of this section. 
(9)  Class G. Food and beverage license for alcoholic beverage sales for commercial passenger vessels on the Missouri River, subject to the following restrictions and conditions: 
a.  The vessel docks and boards passengers at a location within the jurisdictional limits of the city. 
b.  The vessel has a minimum seating capacity for 50 persons. 
c.  Sale and service of on-sale alcoholic beverages may only be made to passengers on the vessel who shall not be permitted to remove alcoholic beverages from the vessel. The sale of off-sale beer is permitted only when made from within an enclosed structure situated on the share adjacent to the vessel's dock, but may not be taken aboard the vessel nor consumed on the vessel. 
d.  The vessel and its operation shall be in compliance with all applicable laws and regulations concerning health, fire and safety. 
e.  Gross sales of food are at least equal to the gross sales of alcoholic beverages. 
f.  Persons under the age of 21 years may be permitted on the vessel in accordance with N.D.C.C. § 5-02-06, provided that the area where persons under the age of 21 years are permitted is separate from the room where alcoholic beverages are opened or mixed. 
g.  Temporary bars may be set up and sale or service of alcoholic beverages permitted to passengers anywhere on the vessel at times when persons under the age of 21 years are not permitted on the vessel. 
h.  The license fee shall be as established by resolution for any seven consecutive monthly periods in the year. 
(10)  Class BWO. The retail on sale of beer and wine only, subject to the following restrictions and conditions. 
a.  May not be in conjunction with any uses other than those in Retail Group A, Service Group A, and Commercial Recreation Group as defined by section 105-1-4. 
[b.]  The license and issuance fee shall be as determined by resolution of the board of city commissioners. 
(b)  This section shall not be construed to require the city to issue licenses for the sale of alcoholic beverages and the board in its discretion, should it deem that a significant number of such licenses have been issued, may refuse to issue any license even though authorized under this section. 
(Code 1979, § 10-03-01; Code 1994, § 12-02-04; Ord. No. 645, § 5, 1981; Ord. No. 783, § 2, 1991; Ord. No. 969, § 1, 2003; Ord. No. 1120, 4-17-2012; Ord. No. 1168, 10-15-2013; Ord. No. 1297, 10-16-2018) 
State Law reference- Local license fees, N.D.C.C. § 5-02-03. 
Sec. 4-2-5. - Class WB license. 
    A class WB license shall authorize the licensee to operate a domestic winery or brewery and to sell wine or beer produced on the premises by the licensee on-sale and off-sale, and to sell wine-making or brewery supplies and related services, subject to the following restrictions and conditions: 
(1)  A class WB license may be issued only to a domestic winery or brewery owner or operator who obtains a license from the office of the attorney general allowing the production of wine or beer. 
(2)  A class WB license shall authorize the licensee to sell, on the winery or brewery premises, wine or beer produced by that winery or brewery on the premises at on-sale or off-sale, in retail lots, and not for resale, in total quantities not in excess of that permitted by N.D.C.C. § 5-01-21 and amendments thereto. In the absence of another appropriate license, sales or delivery of on-sale or off-sale wine, or any other alcoholic beverage produced off the premises shall not be permitted. Licenses under this section entitle the licensee to sell beer manufactured on the premises for off-premises consumption, in brewery-sealed containers of quantities permitted by N.D.C.C. § 5-01-21 and amendments thereto. 
(3)  A class WB license will authorize the licensee to utilize special event permits issued by the office of the attorney general. 
(4)  The class WB license holder may: 
a.  Sell and deliver beer produced by the brewery to licensed beer wholesalers. 
b.  Dispense free samples of beer offered for sale. Complimentary samples of beer may not be in an amount exceeding that permitted by N.D.C.C. § 5-01-21 and amendments thereto, per patron. 
c.  Sell and deliver beer produced by the brewery to licensed retailers within the state, but only if: 
1.  The brewer uses the brewer's own equipment, trucks, and employees to deliver the beer; 
2.  Individual deliveries, other than draft beer, are limited to the case equivalent of that permitted by N.D.C.C. § 5-01-21 and amendments thereto, to each licensed retailer; 
3.  The total amount of beer sold or delivered directly to all retailers does not exceed that permitted by N.D.C.C. § 5-01-21 and amendments thereto; and 
4.  A common carrier is not used to ship or deliver the brewery's product to the public or to licensed retailers. All other sales and deliveries of beer to licensed retailers in this state may be made only through a wholesaler licensed in this state. 
(5)  The class WB license shall be governed by all the provisions of this chapter generally applicable to all license qualifications. 
(6)  The fee for a class WB license shall be as determined by resolution of the board of city commissioners. 
(Code 1994, § 12-02-04.1; Ord. No. 1065, 12-15-2009; Ord. No. 1083, §§ 1, 3, 7-30-2010; Ord. No. 1140, § 2, 2-5-2013) 
State Law reference- Local license fees, N.D.C.C. § 5-02-03. 
Sec. 4-2-6. - Class MP license. 
    A class MP license shall authorize the licensee to sell alcoholic beverages produced within the state and to sell said alcoholic beverages at a location within the city, subject to the following restrictions and conditions: 
(1)  A class MP license may be issued only to a business who obtains a license from the office of the attorney general allowing the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(2)  A class MP license will authorize the licensee to only sell alcoholic beverages produced in the state and no other alcoholic beverages. 
(3)  The class MP license shall be governed by all the provisions of state law and of this article generally applicable to all license qualifications. 
(4)  The fee for a class MP license shall be as determined by resolution of the board of city commissioners. 
(Code 1994, § 12-02-04.2; Ord. No. 1082, 7-16-2010) 
State Law reference- Local license fees, N.D.C.C. § 5-02-03. 
Sec. 4-2-7. - Class DY license. 
    A class DY license shall authorize the licensee to produce distilled spirits, and to sell said distilled spirits at a location with the city, subject to the following restrictions and conditions: 
(1)  A class DY license may be issued only to a business who obtains a license from the office of the state tax commissioner allowing the production of distilled spirits. 
(2)  A class DY license will authorize the licensee to only sell distilled spirits. 
(3)  The class DY license shall be governed by all the provisions of state law and of this article generally applicable to all license qualification. 
(4)  The fee for a class DY license shall be as determined by resolution of the board of city commissioners. 
(Code 1994, § 12-02-04.3; Ord. No. 1101, 8-2-2011) 
State Law reference- Local license fees, N.D.C.C. § 5-02-03. 
Sec. 4-2-8. - Certification of food sales. 
    Any license holder whose premises includes a restaurant and who allows persons under 21 years of age to enter the premises with a request for renewal of a license shall be required to file with the city a statement by a certified public accountant indicating that he has examined and tested the books and records of the licensee and that the licensee's gross revenue from the sale of food is equal to or exceeds the gross revenue from the sale of alcoholic beverages in the dining room. At the option of the licensee, in lieu of a certified public accountant's statement, the licensee may request from the state tax commissioner's office and furnish to the city finance director's office a certified copy of the licensee's sales tax returns for the most recent 12-month period prior to renewal. 
(Code 1994, § 12-02-01; Ord. No. 1117, 4-17-2012) 
Sec. 4-2-9. - License and issuance fees. 
(a)  The license fees shall be payable in advance at the time of the filing of the application. Should a license be granted for an unexpired portion of the term of the license, said fees shall be prorated on the basis of the number of months remaining in such term, determined as of the first day of the month in which such license is issued. No license issued pursuant to the provisions of this section shall be assignable or transferable, and the failure to pay any license fee on or before the date when it is due shall automatically cancel the license. 
(b)  The license and issuance fees shall be as established from time to time by resolution of the board of city commissioners. 
(c)  When a license is not renewed, or is revoked, a one-time only issuance fee, in an amount determined by the board by resolution, shall be paid by any new licensee. The issuance fee shall be in addition to the annual license fee. In lieu of setting an issuance fee, the board may utilize a competitive sealed bidding process for the award of these licenses, may establish a minimum bid or substitute any other procedure for the issuance of a license as determined by the board. 
(Code 1979, § 10-03-06; Code 1994, § 12-02-06; Ord. No. 683, § 3, 1985; Ord. No. 969, § 2, 2003; Ord. No. 1047, 10-7-2008; Ord. No. 1119, 4-17-2012; Ord. No. 1168, 10-15-2013) 
State Law reference- Local license fees, N.D.C.C. § 5-02-03. 
Sec. 4-2-10. - Board approval of license application and site location required. 
(a)  A new license may not be issued to any person to engage in the sale of any alcoholic beverages within the city, nor may any license be transferred to a new or different location without license application and site approval by the board. Prior to the issuance of a new license or approval of transfer of a license to a new or different location, the board shall determine that the proposed site for the licensed business is consistent with the following: 
(1)  Public convenience and necessity. 
(2)  The proposed site meets the site requirements of section 4-1-4. 
(3)  Compliance of the proposed site with applicable building code requirements. 
(4)  Compliance of the proposed site with applicable health and sanitation requirements. 
(5)  Compliance of the proposed site with applicable zoning regulations. 
(b)  The board may also consider: 
(1)  The effect that the proposed siting may have on traffic movements in the area. 
(2)  The number and nature of sites already existing in the area. 
(3)  The general nature, character, age and condition of the development adjacent to the proposed site. 
(4)  The proximity of the proposed site to residential areas, regardless of zoning. 
(c)  Sales of alcoholic beverages in closed containers may be made to persons in motor vehicles at drive-up windows designed for such purpose. However, it shall be unlawful to sell or serve alcoholic beverages in open containers to drivers or occupants of motor vehicles. It shall further be unlawful to serve or sell alcoholic beverages to pedestrians through drive-up windows designed and utilized for sales to persons in motor vehicles. 
(d)  A license application must be approved upon determination of the board that the applicant meets the requirements of this chapter. 
(Code 1994, § 12-02-07; Ord. No. 1115, § 7, 4-17-2012) 
Sec. 4-2-11. - Transfers of licenses limited. 
(a)  No license under the provisions of this article or any interest therein may be transferred to another person without the prior approval of the board. The accumulated transfers of ownership of more than 30 percent of the outstanding stock in any corporation holding a license issued under this chapter, occurring at any time subsequent to the date of the application for a license, shall be reported by the licensee to the city administrator at the time the accumulated total of the transfers exceeds 30 percent of the outstanding stock. The accumulated transfers of ownership of 50 percent or more of the outstanding stock of any corporation holding a license under this chapter, occurring at any time subsequent to the date of the application for a license, shall be deemed to be a transfer of the license and a request for the transfer of the license shall be submitted to the board for approval. The board shall determine what information surrounding the transaction shall be disclosed to the city by the applicant. Any concealment of the facts of the transaction shall be grounds for revocation of the license. 
(b)  Not more than two licenses of each classification shall be issued to any applicant, and each license shall be valid only for the specific premises licensed. 
(c)  No license shall be granted any person who is a member of partnerships possessing two or more retail alcoholic beverage licenses, nor to any person owning more than one percent of the total common or preferred capital stock of any corporations, or combination of corporations, possessing two or more such licenses, nor shall any retail license be issued or granted to any person who is employed in any capacity in connection with any two or more other licensed liquor establishments, nor shall any retail license to sell alcoholic beverages be issued or granted to any member of the immediate family of any person who is the holder of two or more licenses within the city limits. As used in this section, the term "immediate family" means a spouse, child, sibling, parent, grandparent or grandchild, including step-parents, stepchildren, step-siblings, and adoptive relationships. 
(d)  The holder of a class A, D, or D-1 license as of October 15, 2013, shall be permitted to request a transfer of said license on a one-time basis. No further transfers of said license shall be permitted. 
(Code 1979, § 10-03-07; Code 1994, § 12-02-08; Ord. No. 645, § 7, 1981; Ord. No. 1118, 4-17-2012; Ord. No. 1174, 11-19-2013) 
Sec. 4-2-12. - Record of applications. 
    Each license shall be given an identification number and a permanent record thereof must be kept by the city finance director showing the name and the address of the licensee and the legal description of the place licensed. Should the application be denied, the amount deposited for license fees shall be returned. 
(Code 1979, § 10-03-08; Code 1994, § 12-02-09) 
Sec. 4-2-13. - Location limited. 
    No license to sell or distribute any alcoholic beverages under the provisions of this chapter shall entitle the holder thereof to carry on such business at more than one location under one license. No change of location of any business licensed to sell or distribute any alcoholic beverages, shall be permitted without first making application to and receiving the approval of the board. 
(Code 1979, § 10-03-09; Code 1994, § 12-02-10) 
Sec. 4-2-14. - Expiration. 
    Licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall end on June 30 following the date of their issuance unless revoked or suspended as described in this chapter. Any license issued hereunder shall be used by the operations of a facility within six months of its issuance. Failure to use said license within said period of time shall be cause for revocation. In the event of revocation, there shall be no refund of any issuance fee or license fee. 
(Code 1979, § 10-03-10; Code 1994, § 12-02-11; Ord. No. 1173, 11-19-2013) 
Sec. 4-2-15. - Grounds for suspension or revocation. 
(a)  Licenses issued pursuant to this chapter may be suspended or revoked by the board following notice and hearing upon the happening of any one or more of the following contingencies: 
(1)  The death of the licensee, unless upon application to the board by the personal representative of the deceased, the board consents to the carrying on of the business by the personal representative. 
(2)  When the licensee ceases business at the location licensed unless a permit for change of location has been granted. 
(3)  When the licensee is adjudged bankrupt. 
(4)  When the licensee has been convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter, or of N.D.C.C. title 5, or of an offense under any municipal ordinance, state or federal law determined by the board to have a direct bearing upon a licensee's or manager's ability to serve the public as an alcoholic beverage retailer; or, following conviction of any offense, is determined not to be sufficiently rehabilitated under N.D.C.C. § 12.1-33-02.1. 
(5)  When the licensee ceases to possess the qualifications required of an applicant for a license as set out in this chapter. 
(6)  When the federal or state license or permit of the licensee to sell alcoholic beverages at the location licensed has been suspended or revoked. 
(7)  When the business of the licensee at the location licensed is conducted in violation of health or sanitary regulations or other city ordinances. 
(8)  When the licensee, if an individual, or one of the partners or officers if the licensee is a partnership or corporation, is convicted of driving or being in actual physical control of a motor vehicle, or disorderly conduct, provided the conviction is upheld on appeal if an appeal is filed. 
(9)  When the licensee permits persons under 21 years of age, habitual drunkards, obviously intoxicated persons or disorderly persons to frequent his place of business. 
(10)  When the licensee, or any agent, servant or employee shall do any of the following upon the licensed premises: 
a.  Sell or permit the consumption of any alcoholic beverages to any person under the age of 21 years or to an incompetent person. 
b.  Sell any alcoholic beverages to any person while such person is in an obviously intoxicated condition. 
c.  Sell or permit the consumption of any alcoholic beverages upon the licensed premises on any day or at any time when such sale or consumption is prohibited by law. 
d.  Permit on the licensed premises any disorderly conduct, breach of the peace, or any lewd, immoral or improper entertainment, conduct or practices. 
e.  Sell, offer for sale, possess or permit the consumption on the licensed premises of any kind of alcoholic beverages, the sale, possession or consumption of which is not authorized under the license. 
f.  Violate any provision of section 4-1-20 regulating entertainment and live performances upon the licensed premises. 
(b)  The causes enumerated in subsection (a) of this section shall not be deemed to be exclusive and the board retains and reserves unto itself the right to cancel the license for any cause which it may deem sufficient. 
(Code 1979, § 10-03-11; Code 1994, § 12-02-12; Ord. No. 645, §§ 8, 9, 1981; Ord. No. 708, § 2, 1986) 
Sec. 4-2-16. - Notice and hearing on alleged violations. 
(a)  Any person having information that a licensed retailer of alcoholic beverages has violated any provisions of this chapter may file with the city attorney or city administrator an affidavit specifically setting forth such violation. Upon receipt of such affidavit, the city attorney shall set the matter for hearing not later than the next regular meeting of the board or forward such affidavit to the attorney general. If the matter has been set for hearing before the board, a copy of the affidavit and notice of hearing must be mailed to the licensee by first class mail not less than five days before the hearing. A record of the hearings will be made by stenographic notes or the use of an electronic recording device. At the discretion of the board, or upon request of the city attorney or licensee, the hearing may be adjourned from time to time. 
(b)  If, upon completion of the hearing, it appears to the board that a violation of the provisions of this chapter has been established by a preponderance of the evidence, the board may enter an order suspending the license for a time certain, or shall terminate or revoke the license. If, however, the board determines that sufficient evidence of the alleged violation has not been presented, then the license shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Code 1979, § 10-03-12; Code 1994, § 12-02-13) 
State Law reference- Hearing required, N.D.C.C. § 5-02-10; appeals, N.D.C.C. § 5-02-11. 
Sec. 4-2-17. - Special catering permit; fee; penalty. 
    Any qualified alcoholic beverage licensee, except the special class B licensees, may obtain a special catering permit to engage in the sale of alcoholic beverages permitted to be sold under the restrictions of the regular license at an event or public dance, which is located off and away from the licensed premises and on premises designated by the permit. For the purposes of this section, the term "qualified alcoholic beverage licensee" means a licensee who has paid the city lodging and restaurant tax imposed by the city and who continues to pay such tax thereafter. The fee for the permit shall be as established by resolution. The permit shall not be valid for a period of greater than 14 days, and may include Sundays, provided that the licensee meets the qualifications of section 4-2-20. An application for a special catering permit must be filed by the licensee with the city administrator at least 15 days prior to the first day of the event and shall be placed on the agenda for consideration of the board. The application shall contain the name of the licensee, the type of event for which the permit is desired, the specific location at which the event will take place, including a diagram of the area to be licensed, and the date and times for which the permit is desired. The board may establish rules to regulate and restrict the operation of the special catering permit. The licensee granted a catering permit shall be responsible for compliance with all the provisions of this chapter and with any restrictions and special conditions placed on the catering permit by the board.
