    All notice and orders provided for in this article, except in emergency cases, shall be served upon the owner, occupant, mortgagee, lessee and all other persons having an interest in said building as shown by the land records of the recorder of the county, either by serving the same personally or by sending the same to the last known address of each, by first class mail, and a copy of such notice shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the dangerous building to which it relates. Service by first class mail shall be deemed complete on the date of mailing thereof. Such mailing and posting shall be deemed adequate service. 
(Code 1979, § 11-06-10; Code 1994, § 14-09-10) 
Sec. 111-9-11. - Duties of the fire and police departments. 
    Employees of the fire department and police department shall make a report in writing to the building official of all buildings or structures which are, may be, or are suspected to be dangerous buildings within the terms of this article. Such report shall be delivered to the building official within 24 hours of the discovery of any such buildings by any employee of said departments. 
(Code 1979, § 11-06-11; Code 1994, § 14-09-11) 
Sec. 111-9-12. - Administrative liability. 
    No officer, agent or employee of the city shall render himself personally liable for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties under this article. Any suit brought against any officer, agent or employee of the city as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties under this article shall be defended by the city attorney until the final determination of the proceedings therein. 
(Code 1979, § 11-06-12; Code 1994, § 14-09-12) 
Sec. 111-9-13. - Appeals. 
    An appeal to the district court from any order of the board of city commissioners made pursuant to the provisions of this article may be taken, within 30 days after service of such order upon him, by any person aggrieved by said order. 
(Code 1979, § 11-06-13; Code 1994, § 14-09-13) 
ARTICLE 10. - MOVING OF BUILDINGS 

Sec. 111-10-1. - Permit and license required. 
    No person shall move any building over, along or across any highway, street or alley in the city without first being licensed as a house mover by the city and obtaining a permit for house moving from the building official. However, the provisions of this article shall not apply to a person moving a mobile home which is required to be licensed by the state, upon any street in the city, unless the mobile home exceeds the height of the electrical, telephone, telegraph wires or cables situated along or across any such street. 
(Code 1979, § 11-08-01; Code 1994, § 14-10-01) 
Sec. 111-10-2. - Application for permit; fee. 
(a)  Any person desiring to obtain a permit authorizing the moving of a building over, along or across any highway, street or alley in the city shall make application therefor to the building official, upon the form provided by him. The applicant must furnish the following information: 
(1)  A description of the building proposed to be moved, including street number, construction, materials, dimensions, number of rooms and condition of exterior and interior. 
(2)  Proof of ownership and a legal description of the lot from which the building is to be removed, including the lot, block and tract number if located within the city. 
(3)  Proof of ownership and a legal description of the lot to which it is proposed such building be moved, including lot, block and tract number, if located within the city. 
(4)  A description of the portion of the lot to be occupied by the building once moved. 
(5)  A listing of the highways, streets and alleys over, along or across which the building is proposed to be moved, the route and timing of the proposed move is to be approved by the city engineer. 
(6)  The proposed moving date and hours. 
(7)  Sufficient evidence to show that the building and lots from which it is to be removed are free of entanglements and that all taxes, special assessments and city charges against the same have been paid in full. 
(8)  Should the applicant be other than the owner, a written statement or bill of sale signed by the owner, or other sufficient evidence, that he is entitled to move the building, and a copy of the building permit authorizing the removal of the building to a new location is required. 
(9)  Proof that the house mover has liability insurance in the following amounts: 
a.  For injury or death to one person, not less than $250,000.00. 
b.  Subject to the limit for one person, not less than $500,000.00 for injury or death to more than one person. 
c.  For property damage, not less than $50,000.00. 
(b)  The application shall be accompanied by a permit fee in such amount as may be from time to time established by resolution of the board of city commissioners and which shall be nonrefundable. 
(Code 1979, § 11-08-02; Code 1994, § 14-10-02; Ord. No. 760, § 1, 1989) 
Sec. 111-10-3. - Cost of inspection outside city. 
    Should any house or building to be moved be located outside the city, the owner shall deposit sufficient money with the city building official in order to cover the cost of the city for conducting an inspection of such building to ensure compliance with the provisions of this article. Such costs shall include mileage, meals and inspector's salary. 
(Code 1979, § 11-08-03; Code 1994, § 14-10-03) 
Sec. 111-10-4. - House mover's bond required. 
    Before the issuance of the house mover permit, the house mover shall be required to file with the city building official a bond in the sum of not less than $5,000.00, with the form thereof to be approved by the city attorney and the surety by the board of city commissioners, said bond to run to the city and conditioned on the following: 
(1)  The person seeking such permit will pay all damages which may result to the city or to any person residing within the city, or lawfully upon the streets or alleys of the city, as the result of the moving of such house or building, irrespective of whether such damage is to either person or property of any person or to the street, alley or other public property of the city, and whether such damage is caused by the person seeking such permit or his employees. 
(2)  The moving of such structure and the construction, improvement and alterations thereof required for compliance with this article shall be completed within 30 days of the date the house moving permit is issued. For good cause shown, an extension for an additional 30 days may be granted by the board of city commissioners. 
(3)  The person seeking the permit shall keep the city harmless against all liability, judgments, costs and expenses which may accrue against the city as a consequence of acts done by the person in such moving. 
(4)  The person seeking the permit shall meet the conditions of the permit issued to him and the applicable state laws, the provisions of this Code and city ordinances. 
(Code 1979, § 11-08-04; Code 1994, § 14-10-04; Ord. No. 760, § 2, 1989) 
Sec. 111-10-5. - Expense deposit required. 
    Before any house or building is moved as provided in this article, the owner shall supply and furnish to the city a deposit in the amount of not less than $1,000.00, which deposit shall be in the form of cash, certified check or bank money order. The deposit shall cover any expenses incurred by the city to facilitate the move, including, but not limited to, the costs of police escort, tree trimming, movement of municipal utilities and building inspections. Any remaining balance of the deposit after all expenses have been paid will be returned to the owner, provided that the movement, construction, alteration or improvement of the house or building is completed within three months after the permit is issued. If the work is not completed within the required period of time, the balance of the deposit will be paid to the city as liquidated damages, and not by way of penalty. The board of city commissioners shall, by resolution, set the fee schedule for the services required of the city during the moving of any house or building. 
(Code 1979, § 11-08-05; Code 1994, § 14-10-05; Ord. No. 760, § 3, 1989) 
Sec. 111-10-6. - Performance bond required. 
    Prior to the moving of any house or building under the provisions of this article, a performance bond shall be posted with the city building official in the amount to be decided by the board of city commissioners to ensure compliance with all city building codes. 
(Code 1979, § 11-08-06; Code 1994, § 14-10-06) 
Sec. 111-10-7. - Standards of issuance for permit. 
    The building official shall inspect the building and the applicant's equipment to determine whether the standards for issuance of a permit have been met. The building official shall refuse to issue a permit to move a building in the case that the requirements of this article have not been met or in the case that he shall determine the following: 
(1)  That the building to be moved is too large or is in such a state of deterioration or disrepair or is otherwise structurally unsafe that it could not be moved without endangering persons and property within the city. 
(2)  That the building to be moved is structurally unsafe and unfit for the purpose for which it is to be moved, if the removal location is within the city. 
(3)  That applicant's equipment is unsafe so that persons and property within the city would be endangered by its use. 
(4)  That zoning or other ordinances would be violated by the locating of the building in its new position. 
(5)  That the moving of said building will obstruct the orderly flow of traffic. 
(6)  That the axle loading of the moving equipment will be over the legal limit prescribed by the city engineer for the streets over which such moving equipment will pass. 
(7)  That the moving of said house or building will require the trimming of any trees in the public boulevard or on the route designated. 
(Code 1979, § 11-08-07; Code 1994, § 14-10-07) 
Sec. 111-10-8. - Waiver required. 
    Before a house mover's permit shall be issued under the provisions of this article, a petition must be submitted to be signed by 75 percent of the property owners within 300 feet of the proposed building site, should such site be within the city, waiving objection to said structure. 
(Code 1979, § 11-08-08; Code 1994, § 14-10-08) 
Sec. 111-10-9. - House moving agreement. 
    An application for a permit to be issued under the provisions of this article must be accompanied by an agreement to be signed by the owner, under the terms of which the owner promises the following: 
(1)  The house or building will be altered and rebuilt to conform to the requirements of the city building codes, zoning ordinance and other city ordinances. 
(2)  All rubbish and materials will be removed; all excavations will be filled to the existing grade at the original building site, the sewer line will be plugged at the property line and the water service shut off and disconnected at the city water main, all within the time required and performed to the satisfaction of the building official. 
(3)  The building official will be notified prior to moving such house or building and prior to any construction or alteration thereon and inspections requested as required by the building code. 
(4)  The moving of the house or other building will not obstruct the orderly flow of traffic, and the route and timing of the move will be subject to the approval of the city engineer. 
(5)  The house or building will not be moved onto a public right-of-way without providing barricades and signing as required and approved by the city engineer. 
(6)  A police escort will be required for a house or building exceeding 12 feet in width and 13.5 feet in loaded height or as required by the city engineer due to route and timing of move considerations. 
(7)  The moving of the house or building will not damage any trees within a public right-of-way. The owner or his agent shall pay for any necessary tree trimming. All tree trimming shall be performed by a licensed tree trimmer who shall be available at the time of moving. 
(8)  All agencies needed for moving of overhead wires and cables and electricians needed for moving of traffic signals and streetlights shall be available at the time of the moving of the structure. 
(9)  The liability bond, damage deposit and performance bond have been filed with the city prior to the move. 
(Code 1979, § 11-08-09; Code 1994, § 14-10-09; Ord. No. 760, § 4, 1989) 
Sec. 111-10-10. - House moving regulations. 
    Every permittee to move a building under this article shall comply with the following: 
(1)  In the case that the height of the building to be moved exceeds the height of any electric, telephone or telegraph wires or cables strung along or across said street or highway for the purpose of furnishing the inhabitants thereof with lights, heat, power, telephone or telegraph service: 
a.  The person so obtaining said permit for such removal of said building or other structure shall notify the person owning or operating said wires or cables to provide a passageway for said building or structure through said wires or cables at a certain designated time. 
b.  Such notice shall be in writing and shall describe the location of the wires or cables through which the structure is to be moved and shall be served upon said person owning or operating said wires or cables at least 24 hours before said structure is to be removed through said wires or cables. 
c.  The person owning or operating said wires or cables shall upon receiving said notice estimate as near as possible the actual expense for labor and materials in cutting, removing or adjusting said wires or cables, in order to properly allow the passage of said structure and shall notify the parties serving said notice of said required expense, and the party requesting said wires or cables to be cut, removed or adjusted shall deposit with said firm, person or corporation owning or operating said wires or cables the amount required, which shall be in no event more than the actual expense for removing or adjusting said wires or cables 
(2)  Notify the building official in writing of a desired change in moving date and hours as proposed in the application. 
(3)  Notify the chief of police of the proposed time of moving at least 12 hours before the time set for such moving. 
(4)  Move a building only over such streets as have been designated for such use in the written permit issued by the building official. A list of designated streets over which the building may be moved shall be procured by the building official from the city engineer and approved by the chief of police in order to ensure maximum safety to persons and property in the city and to minimize congestion and traffic hazards on public streets, and shall be reproduced upon the permit in writing. 
(5)  Notify the building official in writing of any and all damage done to property belonging to the city within 24 hours after the damage or injury has occurred. 
(6)  Cause red lights to be displayed during the nighttime on every side of the building while standing on a street in such manner as to warn the public of the obstruction and, at all times, maintain barricades across the streets in such manner as to protect the public from damage or injury by reason of removal of the building. 
(7)  Remove the building from city streets after one day of such occupancy, unless an extension be granted by the board of city commissioners. 
(8)  Comply with the building code, the fire code, the zoning ordinance and all other applicable ordinances and laws upon relocating the building in the city. 
(9)  Pay the expense of a traffic officer ordered by the building official to accompany the movement of the building in order to protect the public from injury. 
(10)  Remove all rubbish and materials and fill all excavations to existing grade at the original building site in order that the premises be left in a safe and sanitary condition. 
(11)  See that the sewer line is plugged with a concrete stopper, the water shut off, the meter returned to the city water office and that the gas and electric service companies have been notified to remove their services. 
(Code 1979, § 11-08-10; Code 1994, § 14-10-10) 
ARTICLE 11. - BUILDING DEMOLITION 

Sec. 111-11-1. - Permit required. 
    No person shall begin demolition of any building within the corporate limits of the city and the one-mile extraterritorial jurisdiction as provided for in N.D.C.C. § 40-47-01.1, without first having applied for and obtained a permit to do so from the building official. 
(Code 1979, § 11-09-01; Code 1994, § 14-11-01; Ord. No. 759, § 1, 1989) 
Sec. 111-11-2. - Application for permit; fee. 
(a)  Any person desiring to obtain a permit authorizing the demolition of any building or structure shall make application therefor to the building official upon the form provided. The applicant must furnish the following information: 
(1)  A description of the building proposed to be demolished, including street number, construction, materials, dimensions, and such other information relating to the structure as required by the building official. 
(2)  Proof of ownership and a legal description of the lot on which the building is to be demolished, including the lot, block and tract number if located within the city. 
(3)  Sufficient evidence to show that the building and lots on which the building or structure is to be demolished are free of entanglements and that all taxes, special assessments and city charges against the same have been paid in full. 
(4)  The proposed date and times of the demolition. 
(5)  Proof that the person who proposes to demolish the building has liability in the following amounts: 
a.  For injury or death to one person, not less than $250,000.00. 
b.  Subject to the limit for one person, not less than $500,000.00 for injury to more than one person. 
c.  For property damage, not less than $50,000.00. 
(b)  The application shall be accompanied by a permit fee in such amount as may be from time to time established by resolution of the board of city commissioners and which shall be nonrefundable. 
(Code 1979, § 11-09-02; Code 1994, § 14-11-02; Ord. No. 759, § 2, 1989) 
Sec. 111-11-3. - Bond required. 
    Before the issuance of a permit authorizing the demolition of any building or structure, the person who is responsible for the demolition shall be required to file with the city building official a bond in the sum of not less than $5,000.00, with the form thereof to be approved by the city attorney and the surety by the board of city commissioners, said bond to run to the city and conditioned on the following: 
(1)  The permit applicant will pay all damages which may result to the city or to any person residing within the city, or lawfully upon the streets or alleys of the city, as a result of the demolition of the building, irrespective of whether such damage is to either person or property of any person or to any public property of the city, including streets, alleys and rights-of-way and whether such damage is caused by the applicant or his agent or employee. 
(2)  The demolition of such structure or building, the removal of all debris, the fill and leveling of the lot to grade, and any other work required for compliance with this article or the conditions of the permit must be completed within 30 days of the date the building demolition permit is issued, unless an extension for 30 days is approved by the building official or an extension for a greater period is approved by the board of city commissioners. 
(3)  The person seeking the permit shall keep the city harmless against all liability, judgments, costs and expenses which may accrue against the city as a consequence of acts done by or on behalf of the person in the demolition of the building. 
(4)  The person seeking the permit shall meet all the conditions of the permit and the applicable state laws, the provisions of this Code and city ordinances. 
(Code 1979, § 11-09-03; Code 1994, § 14-11-03; Ord. No. 759, § 3, 1989) 
Sec. 111-11-4. - Expense deposit required. 
    Before any building or structure is demolished as provided in this article, the owner shall supply and furnish to the city a deposit in the amount of not less than $1,000.00, which deposit shall be in the form of cash, certified check or bank money order. The deposit shall cover any expenses incurred by the city to facilitate the demolition, including, but not limited to, the costs of police barricades, tree trimming, movement or disconnection of utilities and building inspections. Any remaining balance of the deposit after all expenses have been paid will be returned to the owner, provided that the demolition, removal of debris and fill and leveling of the lot to grade is completed within 30 days after the permit is issued. If the work is not completed within the period of time required under the permit or any extensions, the balance of the deposit will be paid to the city as liquidated damages, and not by way of penalty. The board of city commissioners shall, by resolution, set the fee schedule for the services required of the city during the demolition of any building or structure. 
(Code 1979, § 11-09-04; Code 1994, § 14-11-04; Ord. No. 759, § 4, 1989) 
Sec. 111-11-5. - Conditions of permit. 
    Demolition permits shall be issued only on the following conditions: 
(1)  Prior to the demolition, the sewer line shall be plugged at the property line and the water service shut off and disconnected at the city water main, within the time required, and performed to the satisfaction of the building official. 
(2)  The structural element shall be taken down one story at a time, beginning with the top floor. All material shall be lowered in chutes or other means to prevent injury to the public. 
(3)  Adjacent streets, alleys and sidewalks shall be protected and pedestrian traffic re-routed, as required by the building official. 
(4)  All debris, rubbish and combustible materials shall be removed from the premises upon completion of the demolition, except the foundation need not be removed if at least 12 inches below finished grade. Upon completion of the demolition, the site shall be filled and leveled with earth to conform to the grade of the adjacent properties and compacted in conformance with the requirements of the building official. 
(5)  The liability bond and damage deposit shall be filed with the city prior to the demolition. 
(6)  The demolition, cleanup and site grading shall all be completed within 30 days of the date the permit was issued. For good cause shown, the building official may extend the period of the permit up to an additional 30 days; however, any requested extension beyond 60 days of the issuance of the permit must be approved by the board of city commissioners. 
(7)  The requirements of this article are deemed to supplement and not replace state laws and all ordinances, rules and regulations for use, occupancy, safety and sanitation. The applicant or person demolishing the building or structure shall comply with all applicable provisions of the fire prevention code and building code. 
(Code 1979, § 11-09-05; Code 1994, § 14-11-05; Ord. No. 759, § 5, 1989) 
ARTICLE 12. - BUILDING AND LOT NUMBERS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate numbering of houses and lots, N.D.C.C. § 40-05-01(19). 

Sec. 111-12-1. - Building numbering. 
    Building numbering shall conform to the requirements of the state building code as augmented herein. 
(1)  Each public entrance to a building shall have the building number affixed in a conspicuous place near the entrance. 
(2)  Entrance numbers shall be a minimum of four inches in height with a minimum stroke width of 1/2 inch. 
(3)  Entrance numbers shall contrast with their background. 
(4)  Where a building is addressed off a private street or is accessed by means of a private driveway and the building address cannot be viewed from a public street, additional signage must be provided by means of one of the following: 
a.  A monument pole located adjacent to the public street; 
b.  A building number and street name on the wall of the building of a size readable by someone of normal vision from the travel lane of the public street that contrasts with the background surrounding the number and name and is either reflective or illuminated; or 
c.  Any other style of signage acceptable to the fire chief. 
(Code 1979, § 8-05-02; Code 1994, § 10-01-01; Ord. No. 1240, § 1, 6-21-2016) 
Sec. 111-12-2. - Lot numbering. 
(a)  Lot numbering shall conform to the number grid established for emergency response purposes by the County of Morton and approved by the City of Mandan. 
(b)  The building official is responsible for assigning the building number at the time of issuance of a building permit. 
(Code 1979, § 8-05-01; Code 1994, § 10-01-02; Ord. No. 1240, § 1, 6-21-2016) 
ARTICLE 13. - OCCUPATION OF RECREATIONAL VEHICLES OR CAMPERS 

Sec. 111-13-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Camper vehicle means a vehicle, whether factory- or home-built, whether on- or off-wheels, whether towed or carried on a motor vehicle or self-propelled, including, but not limited to, recreational vehicles, hitch-mount, pull-behind trailers, pop-up tent trailers, campers meant to be affixed to the bed of trucks and converted vehicles, such as buses, trucks, or trailers. Such vehicles may be with or without complete kitchen and toilet facilities, self-container water and sewage systems and designed to be used as a temporary dwelling for travel, recreation, or vacation use. The term "camper vehicle" does not include mobile homes, manufactured homes and park models. 
    Occupy means to take residence in. 
    Other form of nonpermanent structure includes, but is not limited to, mobile homes, manufactured homes and park models. 
    Park models are recreational homes primarily designed as temporary living quarters for recreation, camping or seasonal use. These homes are built on a single chassis and mounted on wheels. Each park model home is certified by the Recreational Park Trailer Industry Association member manufacturer as complying with ANSI A119.5, a recreational vehicle building code. 
    Person means natural person, partnerships, associations, and all other bodies, corporate or public. 
    Within the City of Mandan or within the city includes, but is not limited to, city streets, commercial/industrial sites, private property, established residential neighborhoods and construction sites. 
(Code 1994, § 14-12-01; Ord. No. 1132, 11-20-2012) 
Sec. 111-13-2. - Purpose. 
(a)  The purpose of this article is to limit the use of camper vehicles and other nonpermanent structures for permanent human habitation, because it is the determination of the city commission that their use in the city for permanent human habitation is deleterious to the health, safety and welfare, not only of the persons residing therein but additionally, of the public at large. Portable heating devices, nonstandard electrical connections, a lack of approved sanitary facilities, including, but not limited to, bathrooms with toilets, sinks or showers or bathtubs and standard kitchen facilities, among other facilities associated with safe places of permanent human habitation, all lend themselves to unhealthful, unsanitary and hazardous living conditions, if utilized for extended periods of time, occasioned in part because camper vehicles and other nonpermanent structures are not intended for use as places of permanent human habitation and to not adequately provide for the needs associated with human habitation. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the foregoing, this article shall make allowance for safe, comfortable and sanitary use of camper vehicles and other nonpermanent structures for short-term, temporary use for human habitation purposes so as to facilitate enjoyment of camping, hunting, bird watching, silviculture and other outdoor pursuits. 
(Code 1994, § 14-12-02; Ord. No. 1132, 11-20-2012) 
Sec. 111-13-3. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  The use of any camper vehicle or other form of nonpermanent structure for human habitation purposes within any zoning district of the city, with the exception of those in construction sites described in this article, in violation of this article, shall result in the issuance by the city of a warning directed to the owner of the camper vehicle or other nonpermanent structure used for human habitation purposes, if ascertainable, or, if the owner cannot be identified, to the owner of the parcel of real estate upon which it is situated, informing that person of the need to cease and desist from make use of the camper vehicle or other nonpermanent structure used for human habitation purposes. 
(b)  Any person who violates, disobeys, neglects, omits, tries willfully to circumvent the intent of this article, refuses to comply with this article, or resists enforcement of any of its provisions shall be guilty of an infraction, unless that person has met the approved guidelines set in this subsection for construction sites, as set by the planning and zoning department of the city. 
(1)  The allowance is for recreational vehicles only. 
(2)  There will be a maximum of ten units allowed unless otherwise approved by the city building official. The following are the number of units allowed, per site, up to ten units. 
a.  Single-family residential projects: One unit per 6,000 square feet of lot area. (No permit required by property owner, but must comply with subsection (b)(4) of this section.) 
b.  Multifamily residential projects: One unit per six apartment units. 
c.  Commercial projects: One unit per 10,000 square feet of lot area. 
d.  Industrial projects: One unit per 10,000 square feet of lot area. 
(3)  The occupants of the recreational vehicle must obtain a permit issued by the building department every 30 days. Each permit is valid for a calendar month and must be renewed at the end of each month. Each permit must provide the make and model of the recreational vehicle, the license plate number and the legal description of the property the recreational vehicle is to be located on at the time of issuance of the permit. The cost of the monthly permit shall be as established by resolution. The application for the permit must be approved by the city building official. 
(4)  The holder of the permit shall abide by the following rules, or the holder will be found in violation of this article: 
a.  Portable restroom facilities must be provided on site. 
b.  Sites must be kept clean of trash and litter. Wastewater, including all liquid wastes, gray water, black water and mop water must be discharged into the city wastewater sewer system, into an approved on-site sewage disposal or holding system or other approved disposal site. Dumping or disposal of waste at other than approved specific sites shall result in fines or removal of the facility. 
c.  The location of the recreational vehicles on-site must be approved by the city building department, with screening if required by the building official. 
d.  The occupants of the recreational vehicles must be construction workers or homeowners for that particular site. 
e.  The units must be removed if legitimate written complaints are received by the city building department. If the units are not removed when requested, the city building department will have them removed and the cost to be assessed to the property. 
f.  Recreational vehicles must be removed and the site must be cleaned up before a certificate of occupancy for the property will be issued by the city building department. 
(c)  Except as otherwise provided, a violation of this article is an infraction. 
(Code 1994, § 14-12-03; Ord. No. 1132, 11-20-2012) 
Sec. 111-13-4. - Exceptions. 
    Residents and family or friends who come to visit may temporarily occupy a camper vehicle on developed property but may only do so for a period of seven days without a permit. Every person residing in a camper under this exception cannot exceed a total of 28 days of occupancy in a calendar year. 
(Code 1994, § 14-12-04; Ord. No. 1132, 11-20-2012) 
Chapter 113 - REMEDIATION 

Sec. 113-1. - Legislative intent. 
    The board of city commissioners declares that it is in the public interest to ensure that environmental remediation of the petroleum hydrocarbon contamination of the soil and groundwater in a 30-acre area of the city be carried out and completed, in accordance with the remedial action plan approved by the North Dakota Department of Health, so as to protect human health and the environment to the extent practicable. The board finds that, when environmental remediation is completed, to the extent practicable, there may necessarily be residual contamination. The board finds that, in such cases, it is necessary to provide an effective and enforceable means of ensuring the conduct of any maintenance, monitoring or operation of remediation systems, of restricting certain uses of, and including placing restrictions on drilling for or pumping groundwater, and of providing certain limitations on the development or improvement of properties as long as any residual contamination remains, as required by the remedial action plan approved by the North Dakota Department of Health. The board, therefore, declares that it is in the public interest to create the Environmental Institutional Control Zoning District to define the area of Downtown Mandan impacted by the contamination and to establish the institutional controls set forth in this chapter for the protection of human health and the environment. As it relates to the institutional controls specifically designated by this chapter, the applicable provisions of this chapter establish the uses, regulations, subdivision, development and administration of land within the district. 
(Code 1994, § 21-10-01; Ord. No. 1002, § 1, 5-19-2006) 
Sec. 113-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Approved remedial action plan or approved plan means the remediation and/or monitoring plan approved and required by the North Dakota Department of Health. 
    Approved remediation system means the treatment infrastructure within the district consisting of the wells, piping and treatment facilities as shown on the approved plan. 
    Corporate counsel or city attorney means the city attorney of the City of Mandan, North Dakota. 
    Department or NDDH means the North Dakota Department of Health, an administrative agency of the State of North Dakota. 
    District means the 30-acre area of the city comprising the environmental institutional control district defined in Ordinance No. 1002. 
    Financial assurance means the insurance coverage or other financial assurance required by the department for any environmental monitoring or remediation that may become necessary on properties within the district notwithstanding the institutional controls established by this chapter and/or responsibility exemptions established by the department. 
    Health and safety plan means the site-specific health and safety plan, approved by the department, for the protection of public health, during the construction and implementation of the approved remedial action plan at the site. 
    Institutional controls are restrictions on the use and management of real property within the district, including use and management of buildings or fixtures that contain or prevent migration of petroleum contamination, or protect receptors from exposure or the threat of exposure to petroleum contamination. Institutional controls may apply during environmental remediation activities or may apply to residual petroleum contamination or their byproducts that may remain on property within the district after active environmental remediation activities are concluded or while natural attenuation of petroleum contamination is occurring. 
    On-site health and safety officer means the person responsible, under the health and safety plan, for enforcing its provisions, communicating hazards, providing access to safety equipment, air monitoring and directing emergency situations. 
    Petroleum contamination means the soil and groundwater contamination in the district resulting from releases of petroleum hydrocarbons at and from railroad storage, fueling and operating activities as defined in Appendix C to Ordinance No. 1002. 
    Responsible party means a person who caused or contributed to the releases of petroleum hydrocarbons at and from railroad storage, fueling and operating activities, as described in Appendix C to Ordinance No. 1002. 
    Responsibility exemption means and includes letters of no action, letters of no further action and letters of no further remediation issued by the department to the owner of a property located within the district. The term "responsibility exemption" also means and includes fetters of regulatory assurance issued to a lender, with respect to a property within the district pursuant to the provisions of N.D.C.C. § 23-20.3-03.1. 
    State means the State of North Dakota, including the NDDH, the attorney general, and all other agencies and executive officers. 
    Trustees means and includes the Trustees of the Mandan Remediation Trust created under the laws of the State of North Dakota by Declaration dated July 30, 2004, registered with the District Court of Morton County, North Dakota pursuant to N.D.C.C. ch. 30.1-32 on August 19, 2004, and the Trustees of the Mandan Supplemental Environmental Projects Trust created under the laws of the State of North Dakota by Declaration dated July 30, 2004, registered with the District Court of Morton County, North Dakota pursuant to N.D.C.C. ch. 30.1-32 on August 23, 2004, to remediate the petroleum contamination; protect the environment and public health through the implementation of remediation technology and institutional controls; and to alleviate the environmental, economic and other impacts of the petroleum contamination. 
(Code 1994, § 21-10-02; Ord. No. 1002, § 1, 5-19-2006) 
Sec. 113-3. - Delineation of environmental institutional control zoning district. 
    The location and boundaries of the district are shown on Appendix A (map) to Ordinance No. 1002, and the properties included within the district are: Lots 4 to 18, inclusive, Block 6; Lots 1 to 18, inclusive, Block 7; Lots 1 to 18, inclusive, Block 8; Lots 1 to 15, inclusive, Block 9; Lots 3 to 6, inclusive, Block 20; Lots 1 to 12, inclusive, Block 21; and Lots 5 to 12, inclusive, Block 22; all in the Original Plat of the City of Mandan, Morton County, ND; plus those properties between Main Street and the BNSF rail yard beginning just east of 3rd Ave. NW and extending east to 1st Ave. NE. 
(Code 1994, § 21-10-03; Ord. No. 1002, § 1, 5-19-2006) 
Sec. 113-4. - Institutional controls applicable within zoning district. 
(a)  Water well restrictions. Except for such uses or methods in existence before the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, the use or attempt to use groundwater from within the area of the district by the installation or drilling of wells or by any other method is hereby prohibited. 
(b)  Management of petroleum-impacted vapors, soils and groundwater. Any person proposing redevelopment, demolition, excavation, grading or construction activities at properties within the district shall submit to the city administrator or their appointee a contingency plan, approved by the NDDH, to evaluate and manage any petroleum-contaminated soils or groundwater and any potential petroleum vapor impacts. The contingency plan must be prepared by a professional engineer licensed to practice in the state (hereinafter P.E.) and shall have experience in the environmental field. The contingency plan shall protect the public health and the environment by considering, at a minimum, historic water/product intrusion, historic petroleum vapor/odor issues, potential future water/product intrusion, and potential future petroleum vapor/intrusion. The contingency plan shall, at a minimum, also consider the following: 
(1)  Excavation and management of petroleum-impacted soil at a NDDH-approved off-site facility if the concentrations of petroleum in the soils are greater than the concentration deemed by the P.E. to be injurious to human health and/or the utilization of the property; 
(2)  Use of petroleum-contaminated soils encountered at the property as controlled fill under newly constructed parking and roadway surfaces if the concentrations of petroleum in the soils are less than the concentration deemed by the P.E. to be injurious to human health and/or the utilization of the property; 
(3)  Excavation of petroleum-contaminated soils in the building footprints/foundations and management of such soil on site as a part of a project if the concentrations of petroleum in the soils are at or greater than the concentration deemed by the P.E. to be injurious to human health and/or the habitation of the structure; and 
(4)  Evaluate and obtain appropriate permits for the discharge and treatment of petroleum-contaminated groundwater resulting from construction activities. 
(c)  Restrictions on construction of new structures within the district. Any person proposing to construct a new structure within the district shall submit a design for that structure that incorporates engineered controls to mitigate the effects of the potential presence of petroleum in the subsurface to the city administrator or their appointee. The design must be prepared by a P.E., and the design must be approved by the NDDH and must meet additional applicable codes and standards relative to the presence of petroleum. The design shall protect the public health and the environment by considering, at a minimum, historic water/product intrusion, historic petroleum vapor/odor issues, potential future water/product intrusion, and potential future petroleum vapor/intrusion. The design shall incorporate vapor barriers, venting system, groundwater suppression/collection and specialized HVAC as determined appropriate by a P.E. In no case shall any structure or any portion of any structure within the district intended for habitation be located below the ground surface. 
(d)  Health and safety. During construction and implementation of the approved plan, the city manager may designate a health and safety officer to implement and enforce the provisions of the health and safety plan approved by the department for the protection of public health and the environment. A copy of the health and safety plan, as approved by the department, and any amendments or modifications made by the department, shall be filed with the office of the city engineer. 
(e)  Non-interference with approved remediation system. The approved plan provides for the treatment and extraction of petroleum-contaminated groundwater and soil vapor utilizing multi-phase extraction, area-specific soil vapor extraction and bioventing. The approved plan further provides for the installation and operation of the treatment infrastructure within the district consisting of the wells, piping and treatment facilities as shown on the approved plan on file with the city engineer which is incorporated in this chapter as though fully set forth. There shall be no interference with, or disturbance of, the approved treatment system installed in accordance with the approved plan. 
(f)  Access by city or NDDH. The city and the department shall have a right of access to the approved remediation system on properties within the district as necessary and convenient to: 
(1)  Inspect and operate the approved remediation system; 
(2)  To sample petroleum-contaminated soil, groundwater and vapors; 
(3)  To verify compliance with this chapter; and 
(4)  To enforce this chapter. 
(Code 1994, § 21-10-04; Ord. No. 1002, § 1, 5-19-2006) 
Sec. 113-5. - Regulatory status of owners within zoning district. 
    The department and the city have entered into a joint agreement, a copy of which is on file in the office of the city administrator, wherein the department has determined that this chapter is an institutional control meeting the requirements of N.D.C.C. § 23-20.3-03.1 applicable to the properties within the district with respect to the petroleum contamination, approving the remedial action plan and determining that owners of properties within the district, as listed on Appendix B to Ordinance No. 1002, are not responsible parties and further determining that the department intends to take no further enforcement action with respect to the petroleum contamination within the district. 
(Code 1994, § 21-10-05; Ord. No. 1002, § 1, 5-19-2006) 
Sec. 113-6. - Financial assurance required by N.D.C.C. § 23-20.3-03.1. 
    The department has determined, as required by N.D.C.C. § 23-20.3-03.1(7), that the potential costs of monitoring and/or remediation which may become necessary to address the petroleum contamination in the district after the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, require a financial assurance in an amount to be determined by the North Dakota Department of Health on a case-by-case basis. The city and the department have entered into a joint agreement concerning payment for or funding of such financial assurance. 
(Code 1994, § 21-10-06; Ord. No. 1002, § 1, 5-19-2006) 
Sec. 113-7. - Coordination. 
    The provisions of this Code regulating land use, planning, zoning, development, subdivision, construction, plumbing, electrical work and architecture, including the following chapters: 
(1)  Architectural Review; 
(2)  Building Code; 
(3)  Building Regulations for Manufactured Housing Installations; 
(4)  Dwelling Construction Code; 
(5)  Electrical Code; 
(6)  Plumbing Code; 
(7)  Gas, Heating and Mechanical Regulations; 
(8)  Housing Code; 
(9)  Substandard Structures; 
(10)  Moving Building; 
(11)  Building Demolition; 
(12)  Planning and Zoning Commission; 
(13)  General Provisions and Definitions; 
(14)  Districts and Uses; 
(15)  District Regulations; 
(16)  Enforcement; 
(17)  Board of Adjustment; 
(18)  Amendments; 
(19)  Master Plan; and 
(20)  Regulations Governing the Subdivision of Land; 
apply to the properties within the district, subject only to the provisions of this chapter providing for the creation of environmental institutional controls, their application, administration and enforcement. Whenever the city receives an application affecting land use or development within the district that may significantly affect an institutional control created by this chapter, the city shall notify the department, and the department shall evaluate whether the application is consistent with the institutional control and shall notify the city in a timely fashion, considering the time frame of the city's review under the applicable provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1994, § 21-10-07; Ord. No. 1002, § 1, 5-19-2006) 
Sec. 113-8. - Recording. 
    This chapter and any amendments thereto shall, upon adoption by the board of city commissioners of the city, be recorded in the office of the county recorder and indexed against the real properties described in Appendix B to Ordinance No. 1002. 
(Code 1994, § 21-10-08; Ord. No. 1002, § 1, 5-19-2006) 
Sec. 113-9. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  The use, development or redevelopment of any land, and the demolition, construction, reconstruction, alteration, or maintenance of any building or structure within the district in violation of this chapter shall constitute the maintenance of a public nuisance and any appropriate action or proceeding may be instituted by the city, through any appropriate administrative official, department, board or bureau charged with the enforcement of this chapter: 
(1)  To prevent such unlawful use, development, construction, reconstruction, alteration or maintenance; or 
(2)  To restrain, correct or abate such violation. 
(b)  A violation of any provision of this chapter, or a failure to comply with any regulation, order, requirement, decision or determination made under authority conferred by this chapter, shall be punishable as an offense as provided in chapter 1. Each day any such violation, failure or refusal to comply continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1994, § 21-10-09; Ord. No. 1002, § 1, 5-19-2006) 
Sec. 113-10. - Enforcement. 
(a)  No permit, license or approval authorized under the provisions of this Code regulating land use, planning, zoning, development subdivision, construction, plumbing, electrical work and architecture, including the provisions cited in section 113-7, shall be issued for any parcel of land, lot, building or structure before the city engineer, building inspector or other responsible city official certifies that the parcel of land, lot, building or structure is in compliance with any applicable controls or limitations required by this chapter. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the city engineer and the city building inspector to enforce this chapter and to bring to the attention of the city attorney any violations or lack of compliance herewith. In the event of any such notice to the city attorney, notice shall also be given to the department. 
(Code 1994, § 21-10-10; Ord. No. 1002, § 1, 5-19-2006) 
Sec. 113-11. - Amendment. 
    The provisions of this chapter, including the institutional controls described in section 113-4, may be amended by the board of city commissioners, provided that public hearings, official notice, and publication of such proposed amendments is given according to the provisions of N.D.C.C. § 40-47-04, and also provided that notice is provided to the department of all proposed amendments and a determination is received from the department that such proposed amendments are protective of the environment and public health. 
(Code 1994, § 21-10-11; Ord. No. 1002, § 1, 5-19-2006) 
Sec. 113-12. - Legislative authority. 
    This chapter is adopted and established by the city pursuant to the authority of N.D.C.C. § 40-47-01 and provides for the establishment of institutional controls that address environmental concerns with the department of health, as provided in N.D.C.C. § 23-20.3-03.1. 
(Code 1994, § 21-10-12; Ord. No. 1002, § 1, 5-19-2006) 
Chapter 115 - STREETS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- General authority relative to streets and sidewalks, N.D.C.C. §§ 40-05-01(8), (10), (12)-(17), (20), 40-05-14; other provisions relative to streets and sidewalks, N.D.C.C. chs. 40-29-40-32; municipal utilities generally, N.D.C.C. ch. 40-33; sewage and garbage disposal, N.D.C.C. ch. 40-34; solid waste management and land protection, N.D.C.C. ch. 23-29. 

ARTICLE 1. - FRANCHISES 

Sec. 115-1-1. - Compliance with applicable laws and ordinances. 
    All companies granted the rights of franchise by the city shall, at all times during the life of said franchise, be subject to all lawful exercise of the police powers by the city and to such reasonable regulation as the city shall hereafter by resolution or ordinance provide. 
(Code 1979, § 7-01-01; Code 1994, § 3-04-01) 
Sec. 115-1-2. - City rights in franchise. 
    The right is reserved to the city to adopt, in addition to the provisions contained in this article and existing applicable ordinances, such additional regulations as it shall find necessary in the exercise of police power, provided that such regulations, by ordinance or otherwise, shall be reasonable, shall not be in conflict with the rights granted in this section and shall not be in conflict with state laws. 
(Code 1979, § 7-01-02; Code 1994, § 3-04-02) 
Sec. 115-1-3. - Company liability; indemnification. 
    All companies granted the rights of franchise by the city shall indemnify and save the city and its agents and employees harmless from all and any claims for personal injuries or property damages and any other claims, costs, including attorney's fees, expenses of investigation in litigation of claims and suits thereon which may arise from the installation and/or operation of said system. 
(Code 1979, § 7-01-03; Code 1994, § 3-04-03) 
Sec. 115-1-4. - Service standards. 
    All companies granted the rights of franchise by the city shall maintain and operate their systems and render efficient service in accordance with the rules and regulations as are, or may be, set forth by the board of city commissioners or by the public service commission of the state. 
(Code 1979, § 7-01-04; Code 1994, § 3-04-04) 
Sec. 115-1-5. - Discriminatory practices prohibited. 
    No company which has been granted the right of franchise by the city shall, as to rates, charges, service facilities, rules, regulations or any other respect, make or grant any preference or advantage to any person, nor subject any persons to any prejudice or disadvantage, provided that nothing in this article shall be deemed to prohibit the establishment of a graduated scale of charges and classified rate schedules to which any customer coming within such classification would be entitled. 
(Code 1979, § 7-01-05; Code 1994, § 3-04-05) 
Sec. 115-1-6. - Conditions of street occupancy. 
(a)  Use. All transmission and distribution structures, lines and equipment erected by any company granted the right of franchise by the city, within the city, shall be so located as to cause minimum interference with the proper use of streets, alleys and other public ways and places, and to cause minimum interference with the rights or reasonable convenience of property owners who adjoin any of said streets, alleys or other public ways and places. 
(b)  Restoration. In case of any disturbance of pavement, sidewalks, driveway or other surfacing, any company granted the right of franchise by the city shall, at its own cost and expense and in a manner approved by the city engineer, replace and restore all paving, sidewalks, driveway or surface of any street or alley disturbed, in as good a condition as before said work was commenced, and shall maintain the restoration in an approved condition for a period of three years. 
(c)  Relocation. In the event that, at any time during the period of franchise, the city shall lawfully elect to alter or change the grade of any street, alley or other public way, any company granted the right of franchise by the city, upon reasonable notice by the city, shall remove, re-lay and relocate its poles, wires, cables, underground conduit, manholes and other fixtures at its own expense. 
(Code 1979, § 7-01-06; Code 1994, § 3-04-06) 
ARTICLE 2. - STREET LIGHTS 

Sec. 115-2-1. - Street lighting system declared. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of N.D.C.C. ch. 40-35, all lands, easements, rights in land, facilities, poles, wires, cables, conduits and other electrical fixtures and equipment necessary or proper for the maintenance and operation thereof heretofore or hereafter acquired by purchase, lease or otherwise and set aside by the board of city commissioners of the city for a municipal street lighting system are declared to be and shall henceforth constitute, be held, operated, maintained, improved, enlarged and administered as a single undertaking to be known as the municipal street lighting system. 
(Code 1994, § 9-05-01; Ord. No. 650, § 1, 1981) 
Sec. 115-2-2. - Under control of board of city commissioners. 
    All properties and other assets set aside or held by the board of city commissioners for such undertaking, and all moneys to be derived from operation of said undertaking shall, at all times, be under the management and control of said board and shall be operated under such rules, regulations, terms and conditions as said board may from time to time establish. 
(Code 1994, § 9-05-02; Ord. No. 650, § 2, 1981) 
Sec. 115-2-3. - Rates and charges established. 
    The board, in order to provide funds to defray the construction, maintenance and repair of the street lighting system, may from time to time, by resolution, establish, maintain and change a schedule of rates, charges and fees for all the services, facilities and benefits furnished by the system and may impose and collect the same monthly at the time and in the manner said board may provide. 
(Code 1994, § 9-05-03; Ord. No. 650, § 3, 1981) 
Sec. 115-2-4. - Rates and charges billed and collected. 
    The rates and charges shall be billed and collected in the manner and time as water, sewer and garbage charges are billed and collected. The rates and charges shall be charged against both the owner of property deemed to be benefited by services of the system and his lessee or agent and shall be a personal liability on the part of each and both and may be collected from either. 
(Code 1994, § 9-05-04; Ord. No. 650, § 4, 1981) 
Sec. 115-2-5. - Self-supporting. 
    Said undertaking shall be so operated and maintained, and the rates and charges for use of its facilities shall be such as to make the undertaking self-supporting and self-perpetuating and adequate to pay all costs of operation and maintenance of said undertaking and to establish and maintain reasonable operating reserves, and to pay all obligations of the city incurred in establishing, improving and extending the undertaking; provided, however, nothing in this article shall be deemed or construed to preclude the city from defraying any part of the expense of the operation or of any improvement or extension of the undertaking by the levy of special assessments or taxes or the issue of general obligation bonds, whenever and to the extent that such action is authorized in the manner provided by law and is deemed fair and equitable by the board of city commissioners. 
(Code 1994, § 9-05-05; Ord. No. 650, § 5, 1981) 
Sec. 115-2-6. - Municipal street lighting system fund created. 
    All moneys received by the city in respect of the service and facilities furnished and made available by said undertaking shall be paid into the treasury of the city and kept in a special fund which shall be permanently maintained on the books of the city, separate and distinct from all other funds, and designated as the municipal lighting system fund, in the records of which fund, all receipts and disbursements of money on account of or in connection with the undertaking shall be deposited, administered and accounted for, and their safekeeping secured, like other city funds. 
(Code 1994, § 9-05-06; Ord. No. 650, § 6, 1981) 
Sec. 115-2-7. - Installation of street lights. 
    The public works director is responsible for operations and maintenance of street lights. The city engineer is responsible for establishing design criteria and approving installation. 
(Code 1994, § 9-05-07; Ord. No. 650, § 7, 1981) 
ARTICLE 3. - DESIGN, CONSTRUCTION AND USE OF STREETS 

Sec. 115-3-1. - Movement of vehicles over curbs prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  Moving vehicle across curb prohibited; exceptions. No person shall move or cause to be moved over any curb within the city any engine, tractor, wagon, motor vehicle, truck or other vehicle, object or thing unless the curb over which the same is to be moved shall be protected by wooden planks or dirt placed or laid in such a manner so as not to cause damage or settling to such curb or any portion thereof when such vehicle, object or thing is moved across such curb; provided, however, that dirt fill shall not be placed within a travel lane of any paved street within the city. 
(b)  Duty to remove fill from curb. It shall be the duty of the owner of the premises abutting such curb and the person placing or constructing such fill to remove the same immediately after such vehicle, object or thing has been moved across such curb. 
(c)  Penalty. Any person violating any of the terms or provisions of this section shall be guilty of an infraction. 
(Code 1979, § 8-02-30; Code 1994, § 10-04-09) 
Sec. 115-3-2. - Responsibility for streets. 
    The city engineer is responsible for the design and construction of streets. The public works department is responsible for maintenance of streets. 
(Code 1979, § 8-01-01; Code 1994, § 10-03-01) 
Sec. 115-3-3. - Street specifications. 
    All construction, maintenance and repair of streets, alleys and other public ways shall be made in conformity with specifications laid down or approved from time to time by the board of city commissioners. 
(Code 1979, § 8-01-03; Code 1994, § 10-03-02) 
Sec. 115-3-4. - Petition by property owners for street improvement; bond required. 
(a)  The owners of at least 50 percent of the property adjacent to any street, alley or public place may file a written petition to the board of city commissioners to have any such street, alley or public place opened, laid out, widened or enlarged. 
(b)  Such petition shall be filed in the office of the city administrator and shall be accompanied by a cash deposit or bond to be approved by the city commission and in an amount equal to the estimated cost of surveying and platting the proposed improvement as determined by the city engineer, guaranteeing the payment of such costs to the city in the event such improvement is not undertaken. 
(c)  Upon city acceptance of the cash deposit or bond submitted by petitioners, the board of city commissioners shall order the city engineer to make an accurate survey, plat and estimate of probable cost of the proposed improvement. 
(d)  Upon completion of the survey and estimate of probable cost, the city engineer shall notify the applicant and gain written approval to proceed with the project. 
(Code 1979, § 8-02-20; Code 1994, § 10-03-03) 
Sec. 115-3-5. - Initiation of street improvement by board. 
    Whenever the board of city commissioners shall determine it necessary to open, lay out, widen or enlarge any street, alley or public place within the city, it shall cause an accurate survey and plat thereof, together with an estimate of the probable cost of the improvement to be made by the city engineer and filed in the office of the city engineer. Should the board of city commissioners determine subsequent to the filing of the same, that the cost of such improvement will not exceed the benefit to the property affected thereby and that such improvement is necessary, the board of city commissioners may order the improvements to be done, the costs thereof to be assessed in the manner provided by state statute. 
(Code 1979, § 8-02-21; Code 1994, § 10-03-04) 
Sec. 115-3-6. - Order and assessment. 
    Upon receipt of survey, plat and estimate of cost of the proposed improvement and finding that such improvement is necessary and that the cost of such improvement will not exceed the benefits to accrue to the properties affected thereby, the board of city commissioners may order such improvement to be made by the city's employees or by a contractor, employed for such purposes, and the cost thereof to be assessed, certified and levied by the city in the manner provided by state statute. 
(Code 1979, § 8-02-23; Code 1994, § 10-03-05) 
Sec. 115-3-7. - Construction bids. 
    Upon ordering the construction or improvement of streets, the board of city commissioners shall direct the city engineer to advertise for bids in the manner prescribed by state statute. 
(Code 1979, § 8-02-23; Code 1994, § 10-03-06) 
Sec. 115-3-8. - Use of streets, alleys and public rights-of-way or easements. 
(a)  Obstructions . No person shall re-grade or place any object in a street, alley, public right-of-way or public easement that restricts the public's use of the street, alley, public right-of-way or public easement unless authorized to do so by the city. No person shall deposit on any street, alley, public right-of-way or public easement any material, either solid or liquid, which may be harmful to the pavement or vegetation thereof or which may do injury to or render unclean any person, animal or property including oil or other chemicals, snow, dirt, rubbish or garbage and grass cuttings or tree limbs. 
(b)  Wires and poles . No person shall erect any pole or install any wire within the right-of-way of any street or alley, any public right-of-way or any public easement without first obtaining permission and any required permit from the city. No person shall remove any wire crossing or running along any street or alley right-of-way, public right-of-way or public easement or any pole within the right-of-way of any street or alley, any public right-of-way or any public easement without first obtaining permission from the owner of the wire or pole, notifying the city of the intended removal and obtaining any required permit from the city for working within the public right-of-way. 
(c)  Building materials . The unpaved boulevard area of a public right-of-way adjacent to a private lot where construction activity authorized by a valid current building permit is in progress may be used to store construction equipment and materials. The paved portion of the public right-of-way may not be used unless written permission is granted by the city. Once seasonal weather conditions prevent continuation of construction activity, the construction equipment and materials must be removed from the boulevard. 
(d)  Sidewalks and street gutters . It is the responsibility of every property owner to maintain the sidewalk and street gutter areas adjacent to their private property free and clear of any obstructions. 
(Ord. No. 1222, § 1b, 11-3-2015) 
ARTICLE 4. - VEGETATION ON BOULEVARDS 

Sec. 115-4-1. - Plantings in boulevards. 
    No person shall plant any vegetable or other plant intended to provide food for human or animal consumption in any boulevard within the city. No person shall plant any bush, shrub or tree in any boulevard without first having obtained a permit from the city forester or other city official authorized to issue such permit. 
(Code 1979, §§ 8-03-01, 8-03-02; Code 1994, §§ 10-10-01, 10-10-02) 
Sec. 115-4-2. - List of approved plants for use in boulevards. 
    The city forester shall create and maintain a list of plants that are approved for use in boulevards within the city. Accompanying the list shall be placement requirements including the mixing of species within a boulevard area, spacing between plants and locations within a boulevard where plantings are not permitted. 
Sec. 115-4-3. - Application for permit. 
    Application for the permit required by this article shall be submitted to the city engineer who shall forward the application to the city forester for review and approval. The city engineer shall then issue the permit after determining that there are no issues related to public water and sewer service. 
(Code 1979, § 8-03-03; Code 1994, § 10-10-03) 
Sec. 115-4-4. - Conditions for issuance of permit. 
(a)  The city forester shall not approve any permit required by the provisions of this article unless the following provisions have been met: 
(1)  The boulevards to be planted have been brought to the final grade as established by the city engineer; 
(2)  In new plantings, the trees shall be planted in a row parallel with and five feet from the property line side of the boulevard. In old plantings, the trees shall be planted in a line with the existing old trees situated in the block; 
(3)  In new subdivisions, where boulevards are over ten feet in width, the subdivider has designated the type of trees to be planted in each block, and such species has been approved by the architectural review commission; and 
(4)  The trees to be planted are not less than 25 feet apart. 
(b)  The city engineer shall not approve any permit required by the provisions of this article unless the following provisions are met: 
(1)  The locations of proposed trees or bushes will be no closer than 10 feet to a water line or water service line; and 
(2)  The locations of proposed trees or bushes will be no closer than 35 feet to a property corner at a street intersection and no closer than 20 feet to an alley. 
(Code 1979, § 8-03-04; Code 1994, § 10-10-04) 
Sec. 115-4-5. - Tree trimming regulations. 
    It is unlawful for any utility company, property owner, tenant or commercial trimmer to trim trees in any public boulevard unless the following regulations are met: 
(1)  All cuts shall be made with a saw or pruner and only at the nodes or crotches. No stubs shall be left. 
(2)  All dead or rotten limbs in the area shall be removed. 
(3)  All old or new wounds over one inch in diameter shall be treated with a good quality of tree wound dressing. 
(4)  All trees and shrubs shall be trimmed neatly and uniformly around their entire circumference so as to effect a pleasant symmetry. 
(Code 1979, § 8-03-05; Code 1994, § 10-10-05) 
Sec. 115-4-6. - Permit and insurance for commercial tree trimmers required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to do commercial tree trimming in any public boulevard in the city without having obtained a permit therefor from the city, the fee therefor to be determined by resolution of the board of city commissioners. The applicant for said permit shall furnish evidence of liability insurance in amounts specified by resolution of the board. 
(Code 1979, § 8-03-06; Code 1994, § 10-10-06) 
Sec. 115-4-7. - Cause for removal of trees and shrubs; notice; action by city. 
(a)  Any tree or shrub which overhangs any sidewalk, street or other public place in the city in such a way as to impede or interfere with traffic or travel, or within 14 feet of a street or ten feet of a sidewalk level, measured vertically, shall be trimmed by the owner of the premises abutting or of the premises on which such tree or shrub grows so that the obstruction shall cease. Any tree or limb of a tree which has become likely to fall on or across any public way or place shall be removed by the owner of the premises on which such tree grows or stands. 
(b)  Whenever any knowledge or notice is given by the police or any employee of the city to the city forester that any tree or shrub or hedge is kept or maintained in violation of the provisions of this section, the city forester shall cause written notice to be given to the owner or occupant of the property upon which said tree, shrub or hedge is so located, to cut and trim the same in accordance with the provisions of this section, and, within ten days after the serving of such notice, a summons shall be served on the owner or occupant in the manner provided for by law for the service of summons in civil action in the state courts. 
(c)  If, after the serving of the notice provided for by this section, the owner or occupant fails or neglects to cut or trim said tree, shrubbery or hedge within ten days after the service of such notice, the same shall be trimmed in conformity with the provisions of this section by the city forester or under his direction, the cost thereof to be assessed against the abutting property. 
(Code 1979, § 8-03-07; Code 1994, § 10-10-07) 
Sec. 115-4-8. - Wires near trees regulated. 
    It is unlawful for any person to attach any wire or rope to any tree or shrub in any public street, parkway or other public place without the permission of the city engineer. Any person or company maintaining poles and wires in the streets, alleys or other public places, shall, in the absence of provision in the franchise concerning the subject, keep such wires and poles free from and away from any trees and shrubs in such places as far as may be possible, and keep all such trees and shrubs near such wires and poles properly and uniformly trimmed, subject to the supervision of the city engineer, so that no injury shall be done either to the poles or wires or to the shrubs and trees by their contact. The location of such poles and wires shall be approved by the city engineer prior to installation of the same. 
(Code 1979, § 8-03-08; Code 1994, § 10-10-08) 
ARTICLE 5. - DRIVEWAYS 

Sec. 115-5-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Driveway means a privately maintained access within a property from a public right-of-way to a building or vehicle parking area that is owned and maintained by the property owner 
    Driveway apron means the area from the public street to a driveway 
(Code 1979, § 8-01-14; Code 1994, § 10-05-01; Ord. No. 773, § 1, 1990; Ord. No. 1060, 8-4-2009; Ord. No. 1197, § 1(10-05-01), 2-3-2015) 
Sec. 115-5-2. - Permit required to construct, repair, alter or widen a driveway apron. 
    Unless performed by a city contractor, a permit is required to construct, repair, alter or widen a driveway apron within any public right-of-way. 
(Code 1979, § 8-01-14; Code 1994, § 10-05-02; Ord. No. 773, § 1, 1990; Ord. No. 1197, § 1(10-05-02), 2-3-2015) 
Sec. 115-5-3. - Permit application and issuance. 
(a)  Permit application. Permit applications for the construction, repair, alteration or widening of any driveway shall be submitted to the city engineer and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name, address and contact information of the property owner or agent in charge of the property abutting the proposed work area; 
(2)  Name, address, contact information, state license number and expiration date, insurance carrier and amount, and bonding company and amount of the contractor doing the work; 
(3)  Estimated cost and location of work; 
(4)  Plans or sufficient sketches showing the details of the proposed work; and 
(5)  Such other information as the city engineer finds reasonably necessary to determine whether or not a permit may be issued hereunder. 
(b)  Application fee. The application shall be accompanied by a fee as determined from time to time by resolution of the board. 
(c)  Application issuance. The city engineer shall issue a permit if a determination is made that: 
(1)  The work will be done according to the standard specifications of the city for public work of like character; 
(2)  The operation will not unreasonably interfere with vehicular and pedestrian traffic, the demand and necessity for parking spaces, and the means of ingress and egress to and from the property affected and adjacent properties; and 
(3)  The health, welfare and safety of the public will not be unreasonably impaired. 
(Code 1979, § 8-01-14; Code 1994, § 10-05-03; Ord. No. 773, § 1, 1990; Ord. No. 1197, § 1(10-05-03), 2-3-2015) 
Sec. 115-5-4. - Driveway apron construction standards. 
    All driveways aprons, including existing driveway aprons for which a permit to repair, alter or widen is sought, must be constructed to meet the following standards: 
(1)  Conflict with nonaccess lines prohibited. A driveway or driveway apron may not be constructed so as to be in conflict with the nonaccess lines shown on the plat or the street right-of-way plan on which the proposed driveway or driveway apron is to be located. 
(2)  Connection to paved roadway. All driveway aprons which connect to a paved roadway must also be paved. 
(3)  Fire hydrant. A driveway apron may not be built closer than four feet to a fire hydrant. 
(4)  Removal of existing curb and gutter. Whenever any driveway apron is constructed to connect with the roadway of any street on which curb or curb and gutter is already in place, the curb or curb and gutter must be removed to the first construction joint past the limits of the driveway apron flare. As an alternate, the curb portion of a curb and gutter section may be removed with appropriate concrete sawing equipment leaving the gutter section intact. A triangular-shaped wedge of concrete must be constructed on both sides of the driveway measuring four feet along the curbline and extending to a maximum of eight and one half feet along the driveway apron between the roadway and the sidewalk or sidewalk line, and varying in slope from curb height to sidewalk height as further detailed in the standard specifications at the office of the city engineer. Such work must be done at the owner's expense. 
(5)  Residential lots. Each lot may have one or two driveways. The combined total width of the driveway or driveways shall be no greater than 36 feet, plus any required flares, measured at the curb line. If there are two driveways, they must be separated by a distance of at least twenty-four feet measured at the curb line. If there is a fire hydrant located between the driveways, the twenty-four feet shall be measured from the fire hydrant to the edge of a driveway apron not counting any required apron flare. Except for properties with adjoining driveways that are built up to the property line, the driveway apron must be placed a distance from the property line sufficient to allow for construction of a flare. 
(6)  Nonresidential lots. Any lot not used for residential purposes may have a maximum of two driveways, each not to exceed 40 feet in width, separated by a distance of not less than 24 feet measured at the curbline of each side of the lot that fronts upon a public street. 
(Code 1979, § 8-01-14; Code 1994, § 10-05-05; Ord. No. 773, § 1, 1990; Ord. No. 1197, § 1(10-05-04), 2-3-2015) 
Sec. 115-5-5. - Removal or relocation of public utilities at owner's expense. 
    If the repair, alteration or widening of a driveway apron will necessitate the removal or relocation of public utilities, street lights or fire hydrants, or the adjustment of manhole castings or valve boxes, such work must be done at the property owner's expense, and the work must conform to standard specifications of the city for public work of like character. 
(Code 1979, § 8-01-14; Code 1994, § 10-05-05; Ord. No. 773, § 1, 1990; Ord. No. 1197, § 1(10-05-05), 2-3-2015) 
ARTICLE 6. - SIDEWALKS 

Sec. 115-6-1. - Duty of property owner to construct sidewalk. 
    It shall be the duty of property owners within the city to construct a sidewalk in the public right-of-way adjacent to their property, unless there is an approved plan or agreement that specifies that no sidewalk is required. 
(Code 1979, § 8-01-12; Code 1994, § 10-02-01; Ord. No. 1197, § 1(10-02-01), 2-3-2015) 
Sec. 115-6-2. - Duty of property owner to maintain sidewalk. 
    It shall be the duty of the property owner, of any property along which a sidewalk has been constructed, to maintain the same in good repair and safe condition. Should any such property owner fail to maintain such sidewalk, the city engineer shall direct the property owner to make repairs as may be necessary to restore such sidewalk to a safe condition. Should the property owner fail, in a reasonable time, to follow these directions, the city engineer shall report the facts to the board of city commissioners who shall then proceed, as authorized by state law, to make such sidewalk safe. Any costs incurred by the city in repairing the sidewalk may be assessed to the property. 
(Code 1979, § 8-01-04; Code 1994, § 10-02-02; Ord. No. 1197, § 1(10-02-02), 2-3-2015)
